“Relevant profits”, if the dividend is not paid for a specified period butis paid out of specified profits, means those profits.
“Relevant profits”, if the dividend is paid neither for a specified periodnor out of specified profits, means—
the profits of the last period for which accounts of the body corporatepaying the dividend were made up which ended before the dividend becamepayable, plus
if the total dividend exceeds the distributable profits of that period, somuch of the distributable profits of preceding periods as is equal to theexcess.
In subsection (2)(b) or (4)(b), the reference to distributable profits ofpreceding periods does not include—
profits previously distributed, or
profits previously treated as relevant profits for the purposes of section61, section 799 of ICTA or section 506 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act1970.

For the purposes of subsection (2)(b) or (4)(b), the profits of the mostrecent preceding period are first to be taken into account, then the profitsof the next most recent preceding period, and so on.
In this section “distributable profits”, in relation to a period, meansprofits available for distribution of the period.

The reference in subsection (5)(b) to section 799 of ICTA is withoutprejudice to the generality of paragraph 4(1) of Schedule 9 (references torewritten provisions include references to superseded provisions).
Taking account of tax underlying dividends that is not foreign tax
Non-UK company dividend paid to 10% investor: relief for UK and othertax

If condition A is met, and one of conditions B and C is met, subsection (5)applies for the purpose of allowing, under the arrangements, credit againstcorporation tax in respect of a dividend paid by a company resident outsidethe United Kingdom (“the overseas company”) to another company (“the recipientcompany”).
Condition A is that the recipient company—
controls directly or indirectly, or
is a subsidiary of a company which controls directly or indirectly,
at least 10% of the voting power in the overseas company.
Condition B is that the recipient company is resident in the UnitedKingdom.
Condition C is that—
the recipient company is resident outside the United Kingdom, but
the dividend forms part of the profits of a permanent establishment of therecipient company in the United Kingdom.
There is to be taken into account, as if it were tax payable under the lawof the territory (“territory R”) in which the overseas company is resident—
any income tax or corporation tax payable by the overseas company inrespect of its profits, and
any tax which, under the law of any territory outside the United Kingdomother than territory R, is payable by the overseas company in respect of itsprofits.
For the purposes of subsection (2), one company (“S”) is a subsidiary ofanother company (“P”) if P controls, directly or indirectly, at least 50% ofthe voting power in S.
Tax underlying dividend treated as underlying tax paid by dividend’srecipient
Meaning of “dividend-paying chain” of companies
For the purposes of sections 65, 67 and 70 there is a dividend-paying chainif—
condition A is met, and
one of conditions B to D is met.
Condition A is that a company (“the second company”) pays a dividend toanother company (“the first company”).
Condition B is that there is a third company which is a 10% associate of,and pays a dividend to, the second company.
Condition C is that there is a succession of companies consisting of—
a third company which is a 10% associate of, and pays a dividend to, thesecond company, and
a fourth company which is a 10% associate of, and pays a dividend to, thethird company.
Condition D is that there is a succession of companies consisting of—
a third company which is a 10% associate of, and pays a dividend to, thesecond company, and
two or more companies (the fourth and fifth companies, and so on) each ofwhich is a 10% associate of, and pays a dividend to, the company above it inthe succession.
For the purposes of this section, a company (“X”) is a 10% associate ofanother company (“H”) if H—
controls directly or indirectly, or
is a subsidiary of a company which controls directly or indirectly,
at least 10% of the voting power in X or at least 10% of the ordinary sharecapital of X.
For the purposes of subsection (6), a company (“S”) is a subsidiary ofanother company (“P”) if P controls, directly or indirectly, at least 50% ofthe voting power in S.
Relief for underlying tax paid by company lower in dividend-payingchain
Subsection (4) applies if conditions E and F are met.
Condition E is that there is a dividend-paying chain (see section 64) inwhich—
the first company is the recipient company mentioned in section 63, and
the second company is the overseas company mentioned in that section.
Condition F is that there is underlying tax, payable by a company (“L”)lower in the chain than the second company, that would be taken into accountunder this Part if—
the dividend paid by L to the company (“K”) above L in the chain had beenpaid—
by a company resident outside the United Kingdom to a company resident inthe United Kingdom, and
at the time when the dividend paid by the second company is received bythe first company, and
double taxation arrangements had provided for the underlying tax to betaken into account.
The underlying tax is to be treated—
for the purposes of section 63(5), and
for the purposes of subsection (3),
as tax paid by K in respect of its profits, but see section 66 (limitations).

In applying section 63 for the purpose of deciding whether condition F ismet, read section 63(2) as if “, or at least 10% of the ordinary share capitalof,” were inserted after “at least 10% of the voting power in”.

Section 58 (first method of calculating amount of underlying tax to betaken into account) does not apply for the purposes of subsections (3) and (4)unless the company referred to in subsection (2)(a) is resident in the UnitedKingdom and, even if that company is resident in the United Kingdom, section58 applies for those purposes only—
if K and L are not resident in the same territory, or
in such other cases as may be prescribed by regulations made by theTreasury.
Section 61 (second method of calculation) applies for the purposes ofsubsections (3) and (4) if section 58 does not apply for those purposes.
Limitations on section 65(4)
Section 65(4) is subject to the limitations set out in subsections (2) and(3).
No tax is to be taken into account in respect of a dividend paid by acompany resident in the United Kingdom except—
corporation tax, and
any tax for which the company is entitled to credit under this Part.

No tax is to be taken into account in respect of a dividend paid by acompany resident outside the United Kingdom to another such company unless itcould have been taken into account, under the provisions of this Part otherthan section 65(4), had the other company been resident in the United Kingdom.
Tax underlying dividends: restriction of relief, and particular cases
Restriction of relief if underlying tax at rate higher than rate ofcorporation tax
Subsection (6) applies if—
conditions A and B are met, and
one of conditions C and D is met.
Condition A is that a company (“the claimant company”) makes a claim for anallowance by way of credit in accordance with this Part.
Condition B is that the claim relates to underlying tax on a dividend paidto the claimant company by a company resident outside the United Kingdom (“theoverseas company”).
Condition C is that the underlying tax is, or includes, an amount inrespect of tax payable at a high rate by the overseas company and—
that amount would not be, or would not be included in, the underlying tax,or
any part of that amount would not be included in the underlying tax,
but for the existence of, or but for there having been, an avoidance scheme(see section 68).
Condition D is that—
there is a dividend-paying chain (see section 64) in which—
the first company is the claimant company, and
the second company is the overseas company, and
the underlying tax is, or includes, an amount in respect of tax payable ata high rate by a company lower in the chain than the overseas company and—
that amount would not be, or would not be included in, the underlying tax,or
any part of that amount would not be included in the underlying tax,
but for the existence of, or but for there having been, an avoidance scheme(see section 68).
The amount of credit to which the claimant company is entitled on the claimis to be determined as if the tax payable at a high rate had instead been taxat the relievable rate.

For the purposes of this section, tax payable by a company is “tax payableat a high rate” so far as the amount payable exceeds the amount that wouldrepresent tax at the relievable rate on the profits of the company which, forthe purposes of this Part, are taken to bear the payable tax.
In this section “the relievable rate” means the rate of corporation tax inforce when the dividend mentioned in subsection (3) was paid.
Meaning of “avoidance scheme” in section 67
In section 67 “avoidance scheme” means any scheme or arrangement in respectof which each of conditions A to C is met.

Condition A is that the purpose, or one of the main purposes, of the schemeor arrangement is to have an amount of underlying tax taken into account on aclaim for an allowance by way of credit in accordance with this Part.
Condition B is that the parties to the scheme or arrangement include—
the company which is the claimant company for the purposes of section 67,
a company related to the claimant company, or
a person connected with the claimant company.

Condition C is that the parties to the scheme or arrangement include aperson who was not under the control of the claimant company at any timebefore the doing of anything as part of, or in pursuance of, the scheme orarrangement.
For the purposes of subsection (3)(b), a company (“R”) is related to theclaimant company if the claimant company—
controls directly or indirectly, or
is a subsidiary of a company which controls directly or indirectly,
at least 10% of the voting power in R.
For the purposes of subsection (3)(c), whether a person is connected withanother is determined in accordance with section 1122 of CTA 2010.
For the purposes of subsection (4), a person who is a party to a scheme orarrangement is to be taken to have been under the control of the claimantcompany at all the following times—

any time when the claimant company would have been taken (in accordancewith sections 450 and 451 of CTA 2010) to have had control of the person forthe purposes of Part 10 of CTA 2010 (close companies),

any time when the claimant company would have been so taken if sections 450and 451 of CTA 2010 applied (with the necessary modifications) in the case ofpartnerships and unincorporated associations as they apply in the case ofcompanies, and
any time when the person acted in relation to the scheme or arrangement, orany proposal for it, either directly or indirectly under the direction of theclaimant company.
For the purposes of subsection (5), the claimant company is a subsidiary ofanother company (“P”) if P controls, directly or indirectly, at least 50% ofthe voting power in the claimant company.
In this section “arrangement” means an arrangement of any kind, whether inwriting or not.
Dividends paid out of transferred profits
This section applies if—
a company resident outside the United Kingdom (“company A”) has paid taxunder the law of a territory outside the United Kingdom in respect of any ofits profits,
some or all of those profits become profits of another company residentoutside the United Kingdom (“company B”) otherwise than as a result of thepayment of a dividend to company B, and
company B pays a dividend out of those profits to another company, whereverresident.
If this section applies, this Part has effect, so far as relating to thedetermination of underlying tax in relation to any dividend paid—
by any company resident outside the United Kingdom (whether or not companyB),
to a company resident in the United Kingdom,
as if company B had paid the tax paid by company A in respect of those profitsof company A which have become profits of company B as mentioned in subsection(1)(b).

But the amount of relief under this Part which is allowable to a companyresident in the United Kingdom is not to exceed the amount which would havebeen allowable to that company had those profits become profits of company Bas a result of the payment of a dividend by company A to company B.
Underlying tax reflecting interest on loans
Subsection (2) applies if—
a bank, or a company connected with a bank, makes a claim for an allowanceby way of credit in accordance with this Chapter,
there is a dividend-paying chain (see section 64) in which—
the first company is the claimant, and
the second company is a company resident outside the United Kingdom,
the claimant—
controls directly or indirectly, or
is a subsidiary of a company which controls directly or indirectly,
at least 10% of the voting power in the second company,
the claim relates to underlying tax on a dividend paid by the secondcompany,

that underlying tax is, or includes, tax payable under the law of aterritory outside the United Kingdom on, or by reference to, interest ordividends earned or received in the course of its business by a company (“thereceiving company”) which is—
the second company, or
a company lower in the chain than the second company, and
section 44 would have applied to the receiving company had it been residentin the United Kingdom.

The amount of the credit for the tax mentioned in subsection (1)(e) (“thenon-UK tax”) is not to exceed the sum equal to corporation tax, at the rate inforce at the time the non-UK tax was chargeable, on—
ID − E
where—
* ID is the amount of the interest or dividends mentioned in subsection (1)(e), and
* E is the amount of the receiving company’s expenditure which is properly attributable to the earning of that interest or those dividends.
For the purposes of subsection (1)(a)—
“bank” means a company carrying on, in the United Kingdom or elsewhere, anytrade which includes the receipt of interest or dividends, and
whether a company is connected with a bank is determined in accordance withsection 1122 of CTA 2010.
For the purposes of subsection (1)(c), the claimant is a subsidiary ofanother company (“P”) if P controls, directly or indirectly, at least 50% ofthe voting power in the claimant.
Foreign taxation of group as single entity

Subsections (2) and (3) apply in relation to a claim for credit in respectof underlying tax in relation to a dividend paid by a company resident outsidethe United Kingdom to a company resident in the United Kingdom if, under thelaw of a territory outside the United Kingdom, tax is payable by any onecompany resident in the territory (“the responsible company”) in respect ofthe aggregate profits, or aggregate profits and aggregate gains, of—
that company and another company resident in the territory, or
that company and two or more other companies resident in the territory,
taken together as a single taxable entity.

This Part, so far as relating to the determination of underlying tax inrelation to any dividend paid by any of the companies mentioned in subsection(1)(a) or (b) (the “non-resident companies”) to another company (“the payeecompany”), has effect as if—
the non-resident companies, taken together, were a single company,
anything done by or in relation to any of the non-resident companies(including the payment of the dividend) were done by or in relation to thatsingle company, and
that single company were related to the payee company if the company whichactually pays the dividend is related to the payee company.
In particular, this Part has effect as if—
the relevant profits for the purposes of section 58 is a single aggregatefigure in respect of that single company, and
the tax paid in the territory by the responsible company is tax paid in theterritory by that single company.
For the purposes of this section, a company (“X”) is related to anothercompany (“H”) if H—
controls directly or indirectly, or
is a subsidiary of a company which controls directly or indirectly,
at least 10% of the voting power in X.
For the purposes of subsection (4), H is a subsidiary of another company(“P”) if P controls, directly or indirectly, at least 50% of the voting powerin H.
Unrelieved foreign tax on profits of overseas permanent establishment
Application of section 73(1)
Section 73(1) applies if, in an accounting period of a company resident inthe United Kingdom—

the amount of the credit for foreign tax which under the arrangementswould, if section 42 were ignored, be allowable against corporation tax inrespect of the company’s qualifying income from an overseas permanentestablishment, exceeds
the amount of the credit for foreign tax which under the arrangements isallowed against corporation tax in respect of the company’s qualifying incomefrom that overseas permanent establishment.
For the purposes of subsection (1) and section 73(1), the company’squalifying income from an overseas permanent establishment is the profits ofthe overseas permanent establishment which are—
profits, chargeable under Chapter 2 of Part 3 of CTA 2009, of a tradecarried on partly, but not wholly, outside the United Kingdom, or
included in the profits of a gross roll-up business chargeable undersection 436A of ICTA.
In sections 73 to 78—
* “the company” means the company mentioned in subsection (1),
* “the excess” means the excess referred to in that subsection,
* “the PE” means the overseas permanent establishment mentioned in that subsection, and
* “period A” means the accounting period mentioned in that subsection.
Carry-forward and carry-back of unrelieved foreign tax
For the purposes of allowing credit relief under this Part, the excess isto be treated—

as if it were foreign tax paid in respect of, and calculated by referenceto, the company’s qualifying income from the PE in the accounting period afterperiod A (whether or not the company in fact has any qualifying income fromthat source in the accounting period after period A), or

in accordance with the rules in section 74, as if it were foreign tax paidin respect of, and calculated by reference to, the company’s qualifying incomefrom the PE in one or more of the recent periods, or
partly as mentioned in paragraph (a) and partly as mentioned in paragraph(b).

If in period A the company ceases to have the PE, the excess, so far as itis not treated as mentioned in subsection (1)(b), is to be reduced to nil (sothat none of the excess is to be treated as mentioned in subsection (1)(a)).
If an amount is treated as mentioned in subsection (1)(b) it is not to beso treated for the purpose of any further application of subsection (1).
In subsection (1)(b) “recent period” means an accounting period which isearlier than period A but begins not more than 3 years before period A.
Rules for carrying back unrelieved foreign tax
This section sets out the rules mentioned in section 73(1)(b).
The first rule is that—
credit for the excess, or for any remaining balance of the excess, isallowed against corporation tax in respect of a later recent period, before
credit for any of the excess is allowed against corporation tax in respectof any earlier recent period.
The second rule is that, before allowing credit for any of the excessagainst corporation tax in respect of income of any particular accountingperiod (“period P”), credit for foreign tax is allowed—

first for foreign tax in respect of the income of period P, other thanamounts which are foreign tax as a result of applying section 73(1) to anexcess from an accounting period other than period P, and
then for amounts which are foreign tax as a result of applying section73(1) to an excess from an accounting period before period P.
In subsection (2) “recent period” means an accounting period which isearlier than period A but begins not more than 3 years before period A.
Two or more establishments treated as a single establishment

Subsection (2) applies if, under the law of a territory outside the UnitedKingdom, tax is charged in respect of the profits of two or more overseaspermanent establishments in that territory, taken together.

For the purposes of the provisions of sections 72 to 78 other than theexcepted provisions, those overseas permanent establishments are to be treatedas if they together constituted a single overseas permanent establishment.
In subsection (2) “the excepted provisions” means section 73(2), thissection and section 77.
Former and subsequent establishments regarded as distinctestablishments
If the company—
at any time ceases to have a particular overseas permanent establishment ina particular territory (“the old establishment”), but
subsequently again has an overseas permanent establishment in thatterritory (“the new establishment”),

the old establishment and the new establishment are, for the purposes of theprovisions of sections 72 to 78 other than the excepted provisions, to beregarded as different overseas permanent establishments.
In subsection (1) “the excepted provisions” means sections 73(2), 75 and77.
Claims for relief under section 73(1)
The excess is to be treated as mentioned in section 73(1) only on a claim.
A claim under subsection (1) must specify—
the amount (if any) of the excess which is to be treated as mentioned insection 73(1)(a), and
the amount (if any) of the excess which is to be treated as mentioned insection 73(1)(b).
A claim under subsection (1) must be made not more than—
4 years after the end of period A, or
if later, 1 year after the end of the accounting period in which theforeign tax concerned is paid.
Meaning of “overseas permanent establishment”
For the purposes of sections 72 to 76 “overseas permanent establishment”means a permanent establishment through which the company carries on a tradein a territory outside the United Kingdom.
In subsection (1) “permanent establishment”—
if the arrangements are double taxation arrangements and define theexpression, has the meaning given by the arrangements, and

if the arrangements are double taxation arrangements but do not define theexpression, or if the arrangements are unilateral relief arrangements for aterritory outside the United Kingdom, is to be read in accordance with Chapter2 of Part 24 of CTA 2010.
Action after adjustment of amount payable by way of UK or foreign tax
Time limits for action if tax adjustment makes credit excessive orinsufficient
Subsection (2) applies to a claim or assessment if—

the amount of any credit given under the arrangements is reduced undersection 34, or becomes excessive or insufficient by reason of any adjustmentof the amount of any tax payable either in the United Kingdom or under the lawof any other territory,
the reduction or adjustment gives rise to the claim or assessment, and
the claim or assessment is made not later than 6 years from the time whenall material determinations have been made, whether in the United Kingdom orelsewhere.
Nothing in—
the Tax Acts, and
the enactments relating to capital gains tax,
limiting the time for the making of assessments, or limiting the time for themaking of claims for relief, applies to the assessment or claim.
In subsection (1)(c) “material determination” means an assessment,reduction, adjustment or other determination that is material in determiningwhether any, and (if so) what, credit is to be given.
Duty to give notice that adjustment has rendered credit excessive
This section applies if—
any credit for foreign tax has been allowed to a person under thearrangements,

later, the amount of that credit is reduced under section 34, or becomesexcessive as a result of an adjustment of the amount of any tax payable underthe law of a territory outside the United Kingdom, and
the reduction or adjustment is not a Lloyd’s adjustment (see subsection(5)).
The person must give notice that a reduction has been made or that theamount of the credit has become excessive as a result of the making of anadjustment.
Notice under subsection (2) is to be given—
to an officer of Revenue and Customs, and
within one year from when the reduction or adjustment is made.

If the person fails to comply with the requirements imposed by subsections(2) and (3), the person is liable to a penalty not greater than the amount bywhich the credit has been reduced or has become excessive as a result of theadjustment.

For the purposes of subsection (1)(c), the reduction or adjustment is a“Lloyd’s adjustment” if the consequences of the reduction or adjustment inrelation to the credit are to be given effect in accordance with regulationsunder—
section 182(1) of FA 1993 (regulations about individual members ofLloyd’s), or
section 229 of FA 1994 (regulations relating to corporate members ofLloyd’s).
In this section so far as it relates to capital gains tax “notice” meansnotice in writing.
Schemes and arrangements designed to increase relief: anti-avoidance
Giving a counteraction notice
Subsection (2) applies if an officer of Revenue and Customs considers, onreasonable grounds, that each of conditions A to D of section 82 is or may bemet in relation to a person.
The officer may give the person a notice which—
informs the person of the officer’s view under subsection (1),
specifies the chargeable period in relation to which the officer formedthat view,

specifies, if the amount of foreign tax considered by the officer to meetcondition B of section 82 is an amount of underlying tax, the body corporatewhose payment of foreign tax is relevant to that underlying tax, and

informs the person that, as a result of the giving of the notice, section90(2) will apply in relation to the person’s tax return for the chargeableperiod specified if each of conditions A to D of section 82 is met in relationto that period.
Section 92 (when notice may be given after tax return made) imposes limitson when the power under subsection (2) is exercisable.

In this section “foreign tax” includes any tax which for the purpose ofallowing credit under the arrangements against corporation tax is treated bysection 63(5) as if it were tax payable under the law of the non-UK territory.
In this section so far as it relates to capital gains tax—
* “chargeable period” means tax year (see section 288(1ZA) of TCGA 1992), and
* “notice” means notice in writing.
Conditions for the purposes of section 81(1)
Conditions A to D are the conditions mentioned in section 81(1).
Condition A is that, in respect of any income or chargeable gain—
taken into account for the purposes of determining a person’s liability toUK tax in a chargeable period, or
to be taken into account for the purposes of determining a person’sliability to UK tax in a chargeable period,
there is an amount of foreign tax for which, under the arrangements, credit isallowable against UK tax for the period.

Condition B is that there is a scheme or arrangement the main purpose ofwhich, or one of the main purposes of which, is to cause an amount of foreigntax to be taken into account in the person’s case for the period.
Condition C is that the scheme or arrangement is within section 83.
Condition D is that T is more than a minimal amount, where T is the sum of—
the total amount of the claims for credit that the person has made, or isin a position to make, for the period (“the counteraction period”), and
the total amount of all connected-person claims.

In subsection (5) “connected-person claim” means a claim that any personconnected to the person has made, or is in a position to make, for anychargeable period that overlaps the counteraction period by at least one day.
In this section—
* “chargeable period”, in relation to capital gains tax, means tax year (see section 288(1ZA) of TCGA 1992),

* “foreign tax” includes any tax which for the purpose of allowing credit under the arrangements against corporation tax is treated by section 63(5) as if it were tax payable under the law of the non-UK territory, and
* “UK tax” means income tax, corporation tax or capital gains tax.
Section 286 of TCGA 1992 (meaning of “connected”) applies for the purposesof subsection (6) so far as applying in relation to capital gains tax.
Schemes and arrangements referred to in section 82(4)
For the purposes of section 82(4), a scheme or arrangement is within thissection if it is within subsection (2) or (4).
A scheme or arrangement is within this subsection if—
it is not an underlying-tax scheme or arrangement, and
one or more of sections 84 to 88 apply to it.

For the purposes of this section, a scheme or arrangement is an“underlying-tax” scheme or arrangement if its main purpose, or one of its mainpurposes, is to cause an amount of underlying tax allowable in respect of adividend paid by an overseas-resident body corporate to be taken into accountin a person’s case.
A scheme or arrangement is within this subsection if—
it is an underlying-tax scheme or arrangement, and
one or more of sections 84 to 88 would, on the assumption in subsection(5), apply to it.
The assumption is that the body corporate is resident in the UnitedKingdom.
Nothing in subsection (5) requires it to be assumed that there is anychange in the place or places at which the body corporate carries on itsactivities.
In subsection (3) “overseas-resident” means resident in a territory outsidethe United Kingdom.
Section 83(2) and (4): schemes enabling attribution of foreign tax
This section applies to a scheme or arrangement if—
the scheme or arrangement enables a participant to pay, in respect of asource of income or chargeable gain, an amount of foreign tax, and
all or part of that amount of foreign tax is properly attributable toanother source of income or chargeable gain.
In subsection (1) “participant” means a person who is party to, orconcerned in, the scheme or arrangement.
Section 83(2) and (4): schemes about effect of paying foreign tax

This section applies to a scheme or arrangement if, under the scheme orarrangement, the condition in subsection (2) is met in relation to a person(“C”) who for a chargeable period has claimed, or is in a position to claim,any credit that under the arrangements is to be allowed for foreign tax.
The condition is that—
C pays an amount of foreign tax (“the FT amount”), and

when C entered into the scheme or arrangement, it could reasonably beexpected that the effect of the payment of the FT amount on the foreign-taxtotal would be to increase that total by less than amount X.
In subsection (2)(b)—
* “the foreign-tax total” means the amount found by—
totalling the amounts of foreign tax paid or payable by the participants inrespect of the transaction or transactions forming part of the scheme orarrangement, and
taking into account any reliefs that arise to the participants, including anyreliefs arising to any one or more of the participants as a consequence of thepayment by C of the FT amount, and
* “amount X” means the amount allowable to C as a credit in respect of the payment of the FT amount.
In subsection (3)—
* “participant” means a person who is party to, or concerned in, the scheme or arrangement, and
* “reliefs” means reliefs, deductions, reductions or allowances against or in respect of any tax.
In subsection (1) so far as it relates to capital gains tax “chargeableperiod” means tax year (see section 288(1ZA) of TCGA 1992).
Section 83(2) and (4): schemes about claims or elections etc
This section applies to a scheme or arrangement if under the scheme orarrangement—
a step is taken by a participant, or
a step that could have been taken by a participant is not taken,
and that action or failure to act has the effect of increasing, or giving riseto, a claim by a participant for an allowance by way of credit under thisPart.
The steps mentioned in subsection (1) are steps that may be taken—
under the law of any territory, or
under double taxation arrangements made in relation to any territory.
The steps mentioned in subsection (1) include—
claiming, or otherwise securing the benefit of, reliefs, deductions,reductions or allowances, and
making elections for tax purposes.
In subsection (1) “participant” means a person who is party to, orconcerned in, the scheme or arrangement.
Section 83(2) and (4): schemes that would reduce a person’s taxliability

This section applies to a scheme or arrangement if, under the scheme orarrangement, the condition in subsection (2) is met in relation to a personwho for a chargeable period has claimed, or is in a position to claim, anycredit that under the arrangements is to be allowed for foreign tax.
The condition is that amount A is less than amount B.
Amount A is the amount of UK tax payable by the person in respect of incomeand chargeable gains arising in the chargeable period.

Amount B is the amount of UK tax that would be payable by the person inrespect of income and chargeable gains arising in the chargeable period if, indetermining that amount, the transactions forming part of the scheme orarrangement were disregarded.
In this section “UK tax” means income tax, corporation tax and capitalgains tax.
In this section so far as it relates to capital gains tax “chargeableperiod” means tax year (see section 288(1ZA) of TCGA 1992).
Section 83(2) and (4): schemes involving tax-deductible payments
This section applies to a scheme or arrangement if the scheme orarrangement includes—
the making by a person (“P”) of a relevant payment or payments, and
the giving, in respect of the payment or payments, of qualifyingconsideration.
For the purposes of subsection (1), a payment is a “relevant payment” ifall or part of it may be brought into account—
in calculating P’s income for the purposes of income tax or corporationtax, or
in calculating P’s chargeable gains for the purposes of capital gains tax.
For the purposes of subsection (1), consideration is “qualifyingconsideration” if—
all or part of it consists of a payment made to P or a person connectedwith P, and
tax is chargeable in respect of the payment under the law of a territoryoutside the United Kingdom.
In this section “payment” includes a transfer of money’s worth.
For the purposes of this section, whether a person is connected withanother is determined in accordance with section 1122 of CTA 2010.
Contents of counteraction notice
Subsections (2) and (3) apply if an officer of Revenue and Customs gives aperson a counteraction notice.
The notice may specify the adjustments that, in the view of the officer,section 90 requires the person to make.

If the notice specifies under section 81(2)(c) a body corporate residentoutside the United Kingdom, the adjustments specified may include treating thebody as having paid, or being liable to pay, only so much foreign tax as wouldhave been allowed to it as a credit if—
it were resident in the United Kingdom, and
a counteraction notice had been given to it as regards an amount of foreigntax.

In this section “foreign tax” includes any tax which for the purpose ofallowing credit under the arrangements against corporation tax is treated bysection 63(5) as if it were tax payable under the law of the non-UK territory.
Consequences of counteraction notices
If—
a counteraction notice has been given to a person in respect of achargeable period specified in the notice, and
that chargeable period is a chargeable period in relation to which each ofconditions A to D of section 82 is met,
subsection (2) applies to the person’s tax return for the period.

The person must in the return make, or must amend the return so as to make,such adjustments as are necessary for counteracting the effects of the schemeor arrangement in that period that are referable to the purpose referred to incondition B of section 82.
Counteraction notices given before tax return made
Subsection (2) applies if—
an officer of Revenue and Customs gives a counteraction notice to a personbefore the person has made the person’s tax return for the chargeable periodspecified in the notice, and
the person makes a tax return for that period before the end of the 90 daysbeginning with the day on which the notice is given.
The person may—
make a tax return that disregards the notice, and
at any time after making the return and before the end of the 90 days,amend the return for the purpose of complying with the provision referred toin the notice.
Subsection (2)(b) does not prevent the return becoming incorrect if thereturn—
is not amended in accordance with subsection (2)(b) for the purpose ofcomplying with the provision referred to in the notice, but
ought to have been so amended.
Counteraction notices given after tax return made
This section applies if—
a person has made a tax return for a chargeable period, and
ignoring the restrictions imposed by this section, an officer of Revenueand Customs has power to give the person a counteraction notice in relation tothe period.
The officer may give the person a counteraction notice in relation to theperiod only if a notice of enquiry has been given to the person in respect ofthe return.
After any enquiries into the return have been completed, the officer maygive the person a counteraction notice in relation to the period only ifconditions E and F are met.

Condition E is that, at the time the enquiries were completed, no officerof Revenue and Customs could have been reasonably expected, on the basis ofthe information made available to Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs beforethat time, to have been aware that the circumstances were such that acounteraction notice could have been given to the person in relation to theperiod.
Condition F is that—
the person was requested to provide information during an enquiry into thereturn, and
if the person had duly complied with the request, an officer of Revenue andCustoms could have been reasonably expected to give the person a counteractionnotice in relation to the period.
Section 94 sets out the circumstances in which, for the purposes ofcondition E, information is made available.
Amendment, closure notices and discovery assessments in section 92cases
This section applies if a person is given a counteraction notice inrelation to a chargeable period after having made a tax return for the period.
The person may amend the return for the purpose of complying with theprovision referred to in the notice at any time before the end of the 90 daysbeginning with the day on which the notice is given.
If the counteraction notice is given after the person has been given anotice of enquiry in relation to the return, no closure notice may be given inrelation to the return before the deadline.

If the counteraction notice is given after any enquiries into the returnare completed, no discovery assessment may be made as regards the income orchargeable gain to which the counteraction notice relates before the deadline.
In subsections (3) and (4) “the deadline” means—
the end of the 90 days beginning with the day on which the counteractionnotice is given, or
if earlier, the amendment of the return for the purpose of complying withthe provision referred to in the counteraction notice.
Subsection (2) does not prevent the return becoming incorrect if thereturn—
is not amended in accordance with subsection (2) for the purpose ofcomplying with the provision referred to in the counteraction notice, but
ought to have been so amended.
Information made available for the purposes of section 92(4)
This section applies for the purposes of section 92(4), and in thissection—
* “the period”,
* “the person”, and
* “the return”,
mean (respectively) the chargeable period, the person and the tax returnmentioned in section 92(1).
Information is made available to Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs if thereturn is under section 8 or 8A of TMA 1970 (personal or trustee’s return) andthe information—
is contained in the return,
is contained in the person’s return under that section for either of thetwo immediately preceding tax years,
is contained in documents accompanying a return within paragraph (a) or(b), or

is, or is contained in documents which are, produced or provided by or onbehalf of the person to an officer of Revenue and Customs for the purposes ofany enquiries into a return within paragraph (a) or (b).

Information is made available to Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs if thereturn is under section 8 of TMA 1970 (personal return), the person carries ona trade, profession or business in partnership and the information—
is contained in a return under section 12AA of TMA 1970 (partnershipreturn) with respect to the partnership for the period,
is contained in a return under section 12AA of TMA 1970 with respect to thepartnership for either of the two immediately preceding tax years,
is contained in documents accompanying a return within paragraph (a) or(b), or

is, or is contained in documents which are, produced or provided by or onbehalf of the person to an officer of Revenue and Customs for the purposes ofany enquiries into a return within paragraph (a) or (b).
Information is made available to Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs if thereturn is a company tax return and the information—
is contained in the return,
is contained in the person’s company tax return for either of the twoimmediately preceding accounting periods,
is contained in documents accompanying a return within paragraph (a) or(b), or
is, or is contained in documents which are, produced or provided by theperson to an officer of Revenue and Customs for the purposes of any enquiriesinto a return within paragraph (a) or (b).
Information is made available to Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs if thereturn is under section 8 or 8A of TMA 1970 and the information —
is contained in any claim made as regards the period by, or on behalf of,the person acting in the same capacity as that in which the person made thereturn,
is contained in any documents accompanying such a claim, or
is, or is contained in documents which are, produced or provided by or onbehalf of the person to an officer of Revenue and Customs for the purposes ofany enquiries into such a claim.
Information is made available to Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs if thereturn is a company tax return and the information—
is contained in a claim made by or on behalf of the person as regards theperiod,
is contained in an application under section 751A of ICTA (applicationsrelating to controlled foreign companies) made by or on behalf of the personwhich affects the return,
is contained in any documents accompanying such a claim or application, or
is, or is contained in documents which are, produced or provided by theperson to an officer of Revenue and Customs for the purposes of any enquiriesinto such a claim or application.

Information is made available to Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs if theexistence of the information, and the relevance of the information as regardsexercise of power to give the person a counteraction notice in relation to theperiod—
could reasonably be expected to be inferred by an officer of Revenue andCustoms from information falling within subsections (2) to (6), or
are notified in writing by or on behalf of the person to an officer ofRevenue and Customs.
Interpretation of sections 89 to 94
This section applies for the purposes of sections 89 to 94, and subsection(4) applies also for the purposes of subsection (8).
“Chargeable period”, in relation to capital gains tax, means tax year (seesection 288(1ZA) of TCGA 1992).
“Closure notice” means a notice under—
section 28A or 28B of TMA 1970 (completion of enquiry into personal,trustee’s or partnership return), or
paragraph 32 of Schedule 18 to FA 1998 (completion of enquiry into companyreturn).
“Company tax return” means the return required to be delivered pursuant toa notice under paragraph 3 of Schedule 18 to FA 1998, as read with paragraph 4of that Schedule (company returns).
“Counteraction notice” means a notice under section 81(2).
“Discovery assessment” means an assessment under—
section 29 of TMA 1970 (assessment to income tax or capital gains tax), or
paragraph 41 of Schedule 18 to FA 1998 (assessment on company).
“Notice of enquiry” means a notice under—
section 9A or 12AC of TMA 1970 (enquiry into personal, trustee’s orpartnership return), or
paragraph 24 of Schedule 18 to FA 1998 (enquiry into company return).
“Tax return” means—
a return under section 8, 8A or 12AA of TMA 1970 (personal return,trustee’s return or partnership return), or
a company tax return.
Insurance companies
Companies with overseas branches: restriction of credit
Subsection (4) applies if credit for foreign tax—
which is payable in respect of insurance business carried on by a companythrough a permanent establishment in the non-UK territory, and
which is calculated otherwise than wholly by reference to profits arisingin the non-UK territory,

is to be allowed (in accordance with this Part) against corporation taxcharged under section 35 of CTA 2009 or section 436A of ICTA in respect of theprofits, calculated in accordance with the provisions applicable for thepurposes of section 35 of CTA 2009, of life assurance business or gross roll-up business carried on by the company in an accounting period (in this sectioncalled “the relevant UK-taxable profits”).

For the purposes of subsection (1)(b), the cases in which foreign tax is“calculated otherwise than wholly by reference to profits arising in the non-UK territory” are those cases in which the charge to tax in the non-UKterritory is within subsection (3).

A charge to tax is within this subsection if it is such a charge madeotherwise than by reference to profits as (by disallowing their deduction incalculating the amount chargeable) to require sums payable and otherliabilities arising under policies to be treated as sums or liabilitiesfalling to be met out of amounts subject to tax in the hands of the company.
If this subsection applies, the amount of the credit is not to exceed thegreater of—
any such part of the foreign tax as is charged by reference to profitsarising in the non-UK territory, and
the shareholders’ share of the foreign tax.
For the purposes of subsection (4), the shareholders’ share of the foreigntax is so much of that tax as is represented by the fraction—
[![](/ukpga/2010/8/images/ukpga_20100008_en_019)](/ukpga/2010/8/images/ukpga_20100008_en_019?view=plain)
where—
* A is an amount equal to the amount of the relevant UK-taxable profits before making any deduction authorised by subsection (7), and
* B is an amount equal to the excess of—
the amount taken into account as receipts of the company in calculating thoseprofits, apart from premiums and sums received by virtue of a claim under areinsurance contract, over
the amount taken into account as expenses in calculating those profits.

If there is no such excess, or if the profits are greater than any excess,the whole of the foreign tax is the shareholders’ share; and, subject to that,if there are no profits, none of the foreign tax is the shareholders’ share.

If, by virtue of this section, the credit for any foreign tax is less thanit otherwise would be, section 31(2)(a) does not prevent a deduction beingmade for the difference in calculating the relevant UK-taxable profits.
Companies with more than one category of business: restriction ofcredit
Subsection (2) has effect if—
an insurance company carries on more than one category of long-termbusiness in an accounting period, and
there arises to the company in that period any income or gain (“therelevant income”) in respect of which credit for foreign tax is to be allowedunder the arrangements.

The amount of the credit for foreign tax which, under the arrangements, isallowable against corporation tax in respect of so much of the relevant incomeas is referable (in accordance with the provisions of sections 432ZA to 432Eof ICTA) to a particular category of business must not exceed the fraction ofthe foreign tax which, in accordance with the following provisions of thissection and with the provisions of section 98, is attributable to thatcategory of business.
If the relevant income arises from an asset which is linked solely to acategory of business, the whole of the foreign tax is attributable to thatcategory of business, unless section 98(3) applies.
If the relevant income arises from foreign business assets, the whole ofthe foreign tax is attributable to gross roll-up business, unless section98(3) applies.
If subsection (3) does not apply and the category of business in questionis—
basic life assurance and general annuity business, or
PHI business,
the fraction of the foreign tax that is attributable to that category ofbusiness is the fraction given by—
[![](/ukpga/2010/8/images/ukpga_20100008_en_020)](/ukpga/2010/8/images/ukpga_20100008_en_020?view=plain)
where “the referable part” of the relevant income is the part of the relevantincome which is referable to that category of business by virtue of anyprovision of section 432A of ICTA.
Section 98(2) and (3) apply if the category of business in question isgross roll-up business.
No part of the foreign tax is attributable to any category of businessexcept as provided by subsections (3) to (6) and section 98(2) and (3).

If under this section or section 98(2) and (3) an amount of foreign tax isfor the purposes of this section attributable to gross roll-up business,credit in respect of the foreign tax so attributable is allowed only againstcorporation tax in respect of profits charged under section 436A of ICTA(charge on profits from gross roll-up business).
Attribution for section 97 purposes if category is gross roll-upbusiness
Subsections (2) and (3) apply for the purposes of section 97 in accordancewith section 97(6), and in this section “the relevant income” has the meaninggiven by section 97(1).
If—
section 97(3) does not apply, and
some or all of the relevant income is taken into account in accordance withsection 83 of FA 1989 in an account in relation to which the provisions ofsection 432C of ICTA apply,
the fraction of the foreign tax that is attributable to gross roll-up businessis the fraction given by—
[![](/ukpga/2010/8/images/ukpga_20100008_en_021)](/ukpga/2010/8/images/ukpga_20100008_en_021?view=plain)
where “the referable part” of the relevant income is the part of the relevantincome which is referable to gross roll-up business by virtue of any provisionof section 432C of ICTA.

If some or all of the relevant income falls to be taken into account indetermining in accordance with section 83(2) of FA 1989 the amount referred toin section 432E(1) of ICTA as the net amount, the fraction of the foreign taxthat is attributable to gross roll-up business is the fraction given by—
[![](/ukpga/2010/8/images/ukpga_20100008_en_022)](/ukpga/2010/8/images/ukpga_20100008_en_022?view=plain)
where—
* “INV” is the investment income taken into account in that determination, and
* “the referable part” of INV is the part of INV which would be referable to gross roll-up business by virtue of section 432E of ICTA if INV were the only amount included in the net amount.
The Treasury may by regulations amend subsection (3); and the regulationsmay include amendments having effect in accounting periods during which theyare made.
Allocation of expenses etc in calculations under section 35 of CTA2009
Subsection (2) has effect if—
an insurance company carries on any category of insurance business in aperiod of account,

a calculation in accordance with the provisions applicable for the purposesof section 35 of CTA 2009 (charge on trade profits) falls to be made inrelation to that category of business for that period, and
there arises to the company in that period any income or gain in respect ofwhich credit for foreign tax is to be allowed under the arrangements.

The amount of the credit for foreign tax which, under the arrangements, isto be allowed against corporation tax in respect of so much of that income orgain as is referable to the category of business concerned (“the relevantincome”) is to be limited by treating the amount of the relevant income asreduced in accordance with sections 100 and 101.
In determining the amount of credit for foreign tax which is to be allowedas mentioned in subsection (2), the relevant income is not to be reducedexcept in accordance with that subsection.
If a 75% subsidiary of an insurance company is acting in accordance with ascheme or arrangement and—
the purpose, or one of the main purposes, of the scheme or arrangement isto prevent or restrict the application of subsection (2) to the insurancecompany, and
the subsidiary does not carry on insurance business of any description,

the amount of corporation tax attributable (apart from this subsection) to anyitem of income or gain arising to the subsidiary is to be found by setting offagainst that item the amount of expenses that would be attributable to itunder section 100(1) if that item had arisen directly to the insurancecompany.

If the credit allowed for any foreign tax is, by virtue of subsection (2),less than it would be if the relevant income were not treated as reduced inaccordance with that subsection, section 31(2)(a) does not prevent a deductionbeing made for the difference in calculating the profits of the category ofbusiness concerned.

If, by virtue of subsection (4), the credit allowed for any foreign tax isless than it would be apart from that subsection, section 31(2)(a) does notprevent a deduction being made for the difference in calculating the income ofthe 75% subsidiary.

For the purposes of the operation of this section in relation to any incomeor gain in respect of which credit is to be allowed under the arrangements,the amount of the income or gain that is referable to a category of insurancebusiness is the same fraction of the income or gain as the fraction of theforeign tax that is attributable to that category of business in accordancewith sections 97 and 98.
First limitation for purposes of section 99(2)

The first limitation for the purposes of section 99(2) is to treat theamount of the relevant income as reduced (but not below nil) for the purposesof this Chapter by the amount of expenses (if any) attributable to therelevant income.

For the purposes of subsection (1), the amount of expenses attributable tothe relevant income is the appropriate fraction of the total relevant expensesof the category of business concerned for the period of account in question.
In subsection (2) “the appropriate fraction” means the fraction given by—
[![](/ukpga/2010/8/images/ukpga_20100008_en_023)](/ukpga/2010/8/images/ukpga_20100008_en_023?view=plain)
where—
* RI is the amount of the relevant income before any reduction in accordance with section 99(2), and
* TI is the total income of the category of business concerned for the period of account in question, but if that would result in TI being nil, TI is instead the amount described in subsection (4).
That amount is so much in total of the income and gains—
which arise to the company in the period of account in question, and
in respect of which credit for foreign tax is to be allowed under anydouble taxation arrangements or under unilateral relief arrangements for anyterritory outside the United Kingdom,
as are referable to the category of business concerned (before any reductionin accordance with section 99(2)).
Subsection (4) is to be read with section 104 (determining how much of anyincome or gain is referable to a category of business).
In this section “the relevant income” has the meaning given by section99(2).
Second limitation for purposes of section 99(2)
If—
the amount of the relevant income after any reduction under section 100(1),
exceeds—
the relevant fraction of the profits of the category of business concernedfor the period of account in question which are chargeable to corporation tax,
the second limitation is to treat the relevant income as further reduced (butnot below nil) for the purposes of this Chapter to an amount equal to thatfraction of those profits.
In subsection (1) “the relevant fraction” means the fraction given by—
[![](/ukpga/2010/8/images/ukpga_20100008_en_024)](/ukpga/2010/8/images/ukpga_20100008_en_024?view=plain)
where—
* “RI” is the amount of the relevant income before any reduction in accordance with section 99(2), and
* “the referable share of total relievable income and gains” is so much in total of the income and gains—
which arise to the company in the period of account in question, and
in respect of which credit for foreign tax is to be allowed under any doubletaxation arrangements or under unilateral relief arrangements for anyterritory outside the United Kingdom,
as are referable to the category of business concerned (before any reductionin accordance with section 99(2)).

In subsection (1), any reference to the profits of a category of businessis a reference to those profits after the set off of any losses of thatcategory of business which have arisen in any previous accounting period.
Subsection (2) is to be read with section 104 (determining how much of anyincome or gain is referable to a category of business).
In this section “the relevant income” has the meaning given by section99(2).
Interpreting sections 99 to 101 for life assurance or gross roll-upbusiness
This section has effect for the interpretation of sections 99 to 101 if thecategory of business concerned—
is life assurance business, or
is gross roll-up business.
The “total income” of the category of business concerned for the period ofaccount in question is the amount (if any) by which—
so much of the total income shown in the revenue account in the periodicalreturn of the company concerned for that period as is referable to thatcategory of business,
exceeds—
so much of any commissions payable and any expenses of management incurredin connection with the acquisition of the business, as shown in that return,as is referable to that category of business.

If any amounts are to be brought into account in accordance with section 83of FA 1989, the amounts that are referable to the category of businessconcerned are to be determined for the purposes of subsection (2) inaccordance with sections 432B to 432G of ICTA.
The “total relevant expenses” of the category of business concerned for anyperiod of account is the amount of the claims incurred—
increased by any increase in the liabilities of the company, or
reduced (but not below nil) by any decrease in the liabilities of thecompany.

For the purposes of subsection (4), the amounts to be taken into account inthe case of any period of account are the amounts as shown in the company’speriodical return for the period so far as referable to the category ofbusiness concerned.
Interpreting sections 99 to 101 for other insurance business
This section has effect for the interpretation of sections 99 to 101 if thecategory of business concerned—
is not life assurance business, and
is not gross roll-up business.
The “total income” of the category of business concerned for any period ofaccount is the amount (if any) by which—
the sum of the amounts specified in subsection (3),
exceeds—
the sum of the amounts specified in subsection (4).
The amounts mentioned in subsection (2)(a) are—
earned premiums, net of reinsurance,
investment income and gains, and
other technical income, net of reinsurance.
The amounts mentioned in subsection (2)(b) are—
acquisition costs,
the change in deferred acquisition costs, and
losses on investments.
The “total relevant expenses” of the category of business concerned for anyperiod of account is the sum of—
the claims incurred, net of reinsurance,
the changes in other technical provisions, net of reinsurance,
the change in the equalisation provision, and
investment management expenses,
unless that sum is a negative amount, in which case the total relevantexpenses is to be taken to be nil.
The amounts to be taken into account for the purposes of the paragraphs ofsubsections (3) to (5) are the amounts taken into account for the purposes ofcorporation tax.
Expressions used—
in the paragraphs of subsections (3) to (5), and

in the provisions of section B of Part 1 of Schedule 3 to the [Large andMedium-sized Companies and Groups (Accounts and Reports) Regulations 2008(S.I. 2008/410)](/id/uksi/2008/410?view=plain "Go to item of legislation")which relate to the profit and loss account format (within the meaning ofparagraph 1(1) and (2) of that Schedule),
have the same meaning in those paragraphs as they have in those provisions.
Interpreting sections 100 and 101: amounts referable to category ofbusiness

This section applies for the purposes of the operation of sections 100 and101 in relation to any income or gain in respect of which credit is to beallowed under any double taxation arrangements or under unilateral reliefarrangements for a territory outside the United Kingdom.
The amount of the income or gain that is referable to a category ofinsurance business is the same fraction of the income or gain as the fractionfound under subsection (3).
Apply sections 97 and 98 in relation to—
that category of business,
the income or gain, and
the double taxation arrangements, or unilateral relief arrangements,mentioned in subsection (1),
in order to find the fraction of the foreign tax that is attributable to thatcategory of business.
CHAPTER 3Miscellaneous provisions
Application of Part for capital gains tax purposes
Meaning of “chargeable gain”
In this Part so far as it relates to capital gains tax “chargeable gain” hasthe same meaning as in TCGA 1992 (see, in particular, section 15(2) of thatAct).
Chapters 1 and 2 apply to capital gains tax separately from othertaxes
Subsection (2) applies if foreign gains tax may be brought into accountunder Chapters 1 and 2 so far as they apply for capital gains tax purposes.
The foreign gains tax is not to be taken into account under those Chaptersso far as they apply otherwise than for capital gains tax purposes.
Subsection (2) applies whether or not relief in respect of the foreigngains tax is given under those Chapters so far as they apply for capital gainstax purposes.
Foreign non-gains tax is not be taken into account under those Chapters sofar as they apply for capital gains tax purposes.
In this section—
* “foreign gains tax” means any tax which—
is imposed by the law of a territory outside the United Kingdom, and
is of a similar character to capital gains tax, and
* “foreign non-gains tax” means tax which—
is imposed by the law of a territory outside the United Kingdom, and
is not foreign gains tax.
When foreign tax disregarded in applying Part for corporation taxpurposes
Disregard of foreign tax referable to derivative contract
In applying this Part for corporation tax purposes in relation to acompany, disregard tax within subsection (2).
Tax is within this subsection in relation to a company so far as the tax—
is tax under the law of a territory outside the United Kingdom, and

is attributable, on a just and reasonable apportionment, to so much of anotional interest payment as, on such an apportionment, is attributable to atime when the company is not a party to the derivative contract concerned.
For the purposes of this section, a payment is a “notional interestpayment” if—
a derivative contract specifies—
a notional principal amount,
a period, and
a rate of interest,
the amount of the payment is determined (wholly or mainly) by applying arate to the specified notional principal amount for the specified period, and
the value of the rate is the same at all times as that of the specifiedrate of interest.
Disregard of foreign tax attributable to interest under a loanrelationship
In applying this Part for corporation tax purposes in relation to acompany, disregard tax within subsection (2).
Tax is within this subsection in relation to a company so far as the tax—
is tax under the law of a territory outside the United Kingdom, and
is attributable, on a just and reasonable apportionment, to interestaccruing under a loan relationship at a time when the company is not a partyto the relationship.
Tax within subsection (2) is not to be disregarded under subsection (1) ifthe tax is also within section 109 or 110.
Repo cases in which no disregard under section 108
Tax attributable to interest accruing to a company under a loanrelationship is within this section if—

at the time when the interest accrues, the company has ceased to be a partyto the relationship by reason of having made the initial sale under or inaccordance with any debtor repo relating to the relationship, and
that time is in the period for which the repo has effect.
In this section—
* “debtor repo” has the meaning given by the repo-definition section,
* “the initial sale”, in relation to a debtor repo, means the sale mentioned in condition C in the repo-definition section, and
* “the repo-definition section” means section 548 of CTA 2009.
In this section, a reference to the period for which a debtor repo haseffect is to the period from the making of the initial sale until the earlierof—
the time when the subsequent purchase mentioned in condition D in the repo-definition section takes place, and
the time when it becomes apparent that that subsequent purchase will nottake place.
Stock-lending cases in which no disregard under section 108
Tax attributable to interest accruing to a company under a loanrelationship is within this section if—

at the time when the interest accrues, the company has ceased to be a partyto the relationship by reason of having made the initial transfer under or inaccordance with any stock lending arrangement relating to that relationship,and
that time is in the period for which the arrangement has effect.
In this section—
* “the initial transfer”, in relation to a stock lending arrangement, means the transfer mentioned in section 263B(1)(a) of TCGA 1992, and
* “stock lending arrangement” has the meaning given by section 263B of TCGA 1992.
In this section, a reference to the period for which a stock lendingarrangement has effect is to the period from the making of the initialtransfer until the earlier of—
the time when the transfer mentioned in section 263B(1)(b) of TCGA 1992takes place, and
the time when it becomes apparent that that transfer will not take place.
Special rules for discretionary trusts
When payment to beneficiary treated as arising from foreign source
Subsection (6) applies if each of conditions A to D is met.
Condition A is that a payment is made by trustees of a settlement.
Condition B is that income tax is treated under section 494 of ITA 2007(treatment of discretionary payments by trustees) as having been paid inrelation to the payment.
Condition C is that the income arising under the settlement includes taxedoverseas income.
Condition D is that the trustees certify—
that the payment is one made out of income consisting of, or including,taxed overseas income of an amount, and from a source, stated in thecertificate, and
that that amount of taxed overseas income arose to the trustees not earlierthan 6 years before the end of the tax year in which the payment is made.
The person to whom the payment is made may claim that the payment, up tothe certified amount, is to be treated for the purposes of this Part as incomereceived by the person—
from the certified source, and
in the tax year in which the payment is made.

In this section “taxed overseas income”, in relation to a settlement, meansincome in respect of which the trustees are entitled to credit under this Partfor tax under the law of a territory outside the United Kingdom.
Deduction for foreign tax where no credit allowed
Deduction from income for foreign tax (instead of credit against UKtax)
The amount of any income arising in any place outside the United Kingdom isreduced for the purposes of the Tax Acts—
by any amount which has been paid in respect of non-UK tax on that incomein the place where the income arose, or
if subsection (2) applies, by the lesser amount mentioned in thatsubsection.

This subsection applies if credit would, were it allowable in respect ofthe income, be reduced under section 39 (reduction by reference to accruedincome losses) to the lesser amount given by section 39(5).
If—
income of any person (“P”) is reduced under subsection (1) by an amountpaid in respect of tax on that income in the place where the income arose, and
a payment is made by a tax authority to P, or any person connected with P,by reference to that tax,
the amount of P’s income is increased by the amount of the payment.
Subsection (1)—
has effect subject to section 31(2)(a) (no deduction for foreign tax ifcredit allowed and UK tax calculated otherwise than by reference to the amountreceived in the United Kingdom),
has effect subject to section 143(5) and (6) (no deduction for specialwithholding tax if UK tax calculated otherwise than by reference to the amountreceived in the United Kingdom),
does not apply to income the tax on which is to be calculated by referenceto the amount of income received in the United Kingdom, and
does not require any income to be reduced by an amount of underlying taxwhich, under section 60(3), is to be left out of account for the purposes ofsection 57.
Subsection (1) has effect for corporation tax purposes despite—
section 464(1) of CTA 2009 (matters to be brought into account in the caseof loan relationships only under Part 5 of that Act), and
section 906(1) of that Act (matters to be brought into account in respectof intangible fixed assets only under Part 8 of that Act).
In subsection (1) “non-UK tax” means tax under the law of a territoryoutside the United Kingdom.
For the purposes of subsection (3), whether a person is connected with P isdetermined in accordance with section 1122 of CTA 2010.
Deduction from capital gain for foreign tax (instead of creditagainst UK tax)
Subsection (2) applies to tax if it is—
chargeable under the law of any territory outside the United Kingdom on thedisposal of an asset, and
borne by the person making the disposal.
The tax is allowable as a deduction in the calculation of the gain.
Subsection (2) is subject to—
Chapters 1 and 2 so far as they apply for corporation tax purposes (see, inparticular, section 31),
Chapters 1 and 2 so far as they apply for capital gains tax purposes (see,in particular, section 31), and
section 143 (which includes provision about taking account of specialwithholding tax when calculating a gain for capital gains tax purposes).
In subsection (1) “asset” and “disposal” have the same meaning as in TCGA1992 (see, in particular, section 21 and the following provisions of TCGA1992).
Time limits for action if tax adjustment makes reduction too large ortoo small
Subsection (2) applies to a claim or assessment if—

the amount of any reduction under section 112(1) or 113(2) becomesexcessive or insufficient by reason of any adjustment of the amount of any taxpayable either in the United Kingdom or under the law of any territory outsidethe United Kingdom, or a person’s income is increased under section 112(3),
the adjustment or increase gives rise to the claim or assessment, and
the claim or assessment is made not later than 6 years from the time whenall material determinations have been made, whether in the United Kingdom orelsewhere.
No time-limit rule applies to the assessment or claim.
In subsection (1)(c) “material determination” means (as the case may be)—

an assessment, adjustment, increase or other determination that is materialin determining whether any, and (if so) what, reduction is to be made undersection 112(1) or increase is to be made under section 112(3), or
an assessment, adjustment or other determination that is material indetermining whether any, and (if so) what, reduction is to be made undersection 113(2).
In subsection (2) “time-limit rule” means anything—
in TMA 1970,
in ICTA,
in TCGA 1992, or
in any other provision of the Tax Acts,
limiting the time for the making of assessments or limiting the time for themaking of claims for relief.
Duty to give notice that adjustment has rendered reduction too large
This section applies if—
the amount of any of a person’s income is reduced under section 112(1),

that reduction (“the original reduction”) later becomes excessive as aresult of an adjustment of the amount of any tax payable under the law of aterritory outside the United Kingdom or an increase under section 112(3), and
the adjustment or increase is not a Lloyd’s adjustment.
This section also applies if—
a deduction is allowed under section 113(2) in the case of a person makinga disposal, and
that deduction (“the original reduction”) later becomes excessive as aresult of an adjustment of the amount of any tax payable under the law of aterritory outside the United Kingdom.
The person must give notice that the original reduction has becomeexcessive as a result of the making of an adjustment or increase.
Notice under subsection (3) is to be given—
to an officer of Revenue and Customs, and
within one year from when the adjustment or increase was made.
If the person fails to comply with the requirements imposed by subsections(3) and (4), the person is liable to a penalty not greater than the amountgiven by—
A − B
where—

* A is the amount of tax payable by the person for the reduction period after giving effect to the reduction that ought to be made under section 112(1) or (as the case may be) under section 113(2), and
* B is the amount that would have been the tax payable by the person for that period after giving effect instead to the original reduction.
In subsection (5) “the reduction period” means the tax year, or accountingperiod of a company for corporation tax purposes, for which the originalreduction was made.

For the purposes of subsection (1)(c), the adjustment or increase is a“Lloyd’s adjustment” if the consequences of the adjustment or increase inrelation to the reduction are to be given effect in accordance withregulations under—
section 182(1) of FA 1993 (regulations about individual members ofLloyd’s), or
section 229 of FA 1994 (regulations relating to corporate members ofLloyd’s).
In subsection (2) “disposal” has the same meaning as in TCGA 1992 (see, inparticular, section 21(2) and the following provisions of TCGA 1992).
In this section so far as it relates to capital gains tax “notice” meansnotice in writing.
European cross-border transfers of business
Introduction to section 117
Subject to subsections (4) to (6), section 117 applies if condition A or Bis met.
Condition A is that—

a company resident in the United Kingdom transfers to a company resident inanother member State the whole or part of a business which immediately beforethe transfer the transferor carried on in a member State other than the UnitedKingdom through a permanent establishment, and
the transfer includes—
the transfer of an asset or liability representing a loan relationship,
the transfer of rights and liabilities under a derivative contract, or

the transfer of intangible fixed assets that are chargeable intangibleassets in relation to the transferor immediately before the transfer and inthe case of one or more of which the proceeds of realisation exceed the costsrecognised for tax purposes.
Condition B is that—
a company resident in the United Kingdom transfers part of its business toone or more companies,
the part of the transferor’s business which is transferred was carried onimmediately before the transfer in a member State other than the UnitedKingdom through a permanent establishment,
at least one transferee is resident in a member State other than the UnitedKingdom,
the transferor continues to carry on a business after the transfer,
the condition in subsection (2)(b) is met, and
the transfer—
is made in exchange for the issue of shares in or debentures of eachtransferee to each person holding shares in or debentures of the transferor,or

is not so made only because, and only so far as, a transferee is preventedfrom so issuing such shares or debentures by section 658 of the Companies Act2006 (general rule against limited company acquiring own shares) or by acorresponding provision of the law of another member State preventing such anissue.
If a transfer that meets condition A or B includes such a transfer as ismentioned in subsection (2)(b)(i), section 117—

only applies as respects the transfer so mentioned as a result of thetransfer meeting condition A if the transfer is wholly or partly in exchangefor shares or debentures issued by the transferee to the transferor, and
only applies as respects the transfer so mentioned as a result of thetransfer meeting condition B if each transferee is resident in a member State,but not necessarily the same one.
If a transfer that meets condition A or B includes such a transfer as ismentioned in subsection (2)(b)(ii), section 117—

only applies as respects the transfer so mentioned as a result of thetransfer meeting condition A if the transfer is wholly or partly in exchangefor shares or debentures issued by the transferee to the transferor or to thepersons holding shares in or debentures of the transferor,
only applies as respects the transfer so mentioned as a result of thetransfer meeting condition B if each transferee is resident in a member State,but not necessarily the same one, and
only applies as respects the transfer so mentioned if the transferor makesa claim under this section in respect of it.
If a transfer that meets condition A or B includes such a transfer as ismentioned in subsection (2)(b)(iii), section 117—
only applies as respects the transfer so mentioned as a result of thetransfer meeting condition A if—
the companies mentioned in subsection (2)(a) are companies incorporatedunder the law of a member State, and
the transfer is wholly or partly in exchange for shares or othersecurities issued by the transferee to the transferor,
only applies as respects the transfer so mentioned as a result of thetransfer meeting condition B if—
the transferor and at least one of the transferees mentioned in subsection(3)(a) is a company so incorporated, and
the transfer is in exchange for shares or debentures issued by thetransferee to the persons holding shares in or debentures of the transferor,and
only applies as respects the transfer so mentioned if—
the transfer includes the whole of the assets of the transferor used forthe purposes of the business or part, or the whole of those assets other thancash, and
the transferor makes a claim under this section in respect of the transferso mentioned.

No claim may be made under subsection (6) in respect of a transfer inrelation to which a claim is made under section 827 of CTA 2009 (claims topostpone charge on transfer of assets to non-UK resident company).
For the purposes of this section, a company is resident in a member Stateif—
it is within a charge to tax under the law of the State as being residentfor that purpose, and
it is not regarded, for the purpose of any double taxation reliefarrangements to which the State is a party, as resident in a territory notwithin a member State.
Tax treated as chargeable in respect of transfer of loanrelationship, derivative contract or intangible fixed assets

If tax would have been chargeable under the law of one or more other memberStates in respect of the transfer mentioned in section 116(2)(b)(i), (ii) or(iii) but for the Mergers Directive, this Part applies, and any doubletaxation arrangements apply, as if that tax had been chargeable.
In calculating tax notionally chargeable under subsection (1), it is to beassumed—
that, to the extent permitted by the law of the other member State, lossesarising on the transfer mentioned in section 116(2)(b)(i), (ii) or (iii) areset against gains arising on that transfer, and
that any relief due to the transferor under that law is claimed.
