is not a small enterprise as defined in the Annex.
For the purposes of subsection (1), the Annex has effect with themodifications set out in subsections (4) to (7).
In this section “the Annex” means the Annex to Commission Recommendation2003/361/EC of 6 May 2003 (concerning the definition of micro, small andmedium-sized businesses).

Where any enterprise is in liquidation or administration, the rights of theliquidator or administrator (in that capacity) are to be left out of accountwhen applying Article 3(3)(b) of the Annex in determining for the purposes ofthis Part whether—
that enterprise, or
any other enterprise (including that of the liquidator or administrator),
is a small or medium-sized enterprise.
Article 3 of the Annex has effect with the omission of paragraph 5(declaration in good faith where control cannot be determined etc).
The first sentence of Article 4(1) of the Annex has effect as if the datato apply to—
the headcount of staff, and
the financial amounts,
were the data relating to the chargeable period referred to in section 166(1)(instead of the period described in that sentence) and calculated on an annualbasis.
Article 4 of the Annex has effect with the omission of the followingprovisions—
the second sentence of paragraph 1 (data to be taken into account from dateof closure of accounts),
paragraph 2 (no change of status unless ceilings exceeded for twoconsecutive periods), and
paragraph 3 (genuine estimate in case of newly established enterprise).
Meaning of “qualifying territory” and “non-qualifying territory”
In section 167(3)—
* “non-qualifying territory” means any territory which is not a qualifying territory, and
* “qualifying territory” means—
the United Kingdom, or
any territory in relation to which condition A or condition B is met.
Condition A is that—
double taxation arrangements have been made in relation to the territory,
the arrangements include a non-discrimination provision, and
the territory is not designated as a non-qualifying territory for thepurposes of this subsection in regulations made by the Treasury.
Condition B is that—
double taxation arrangements have been made in relation to the territory,and
the territory is designated as a qualifying territory for the purposes ofthis subsection in regulations made by the Treasury.

For the purposes of subsection (2)(b) a “non-discrimination provision”, inrelation to any double taxation arrangements, is a provision to the effectthat nationals of a state which is a party to those arrangements (a“contracting state”) are not to be subject in any other contracting state to—
any taxation, or
any requirement connected with taxation,

which is other or more burdensome than the taxation and connected requirementsto which nationals of that other state in the same circumstances (inparticular with respect to residence) are or may be subjected.
In subsection (4) “national”, in relation to a state, includes—
any individual possessing the nationality or citizenship of the state, and
any legal person, partnership or association deriving its status as suchfrom the law in force in that state.
In this section “double taxation arrangements” means arrangements that haveeffect under section 2(1) (double taxation relief by agreement withterritories outside the United Kingdom).
Regulations under this section may only be made if a draft of the statutoryinstrument containing the regulations has been laid before and approved by aresolution of the House of Commons.
CHAPTER 4Position, if only one affected person potentially advantaged, ofother affected person
Claim by affected person who is not advantaged
Claim by the affected person who is not potentially advantaged
Subsection (2) applies if—

only one of the affected persons (in this Chapter called “the advantagedperson”) is a person on whom a potential advantage in relation to UnitedKingdom taxation is conferred by the actual provision, and

the other affected person (in this Chapter called “the disadvantagedperson”) is within the charge to income tax or corporation tax in respect ofprofits arising from the relevant activities (see section 216).
On the making of a claim by the disadvantaged person—
the profits and losses of the disadvantaged person are to be calculated fortax purposes as if the arm’s length provision had been made or imposed insteadof the actual provision, and

despite any limit in the Tax Acts on the time within which any adjustmentmay be made, all such adjustments are to be made in the disadvantaged person’scase as may be required to give effect to the assumption that the arm’s lengthprovision was made or imposed instead of the actual provision.
Provision about claims under this section is made by—
* section 175 (claim not allowed in some cases where actual provision relates to a security issued by one of the affected persons),
* section 176 (claim cannot be made unless advantaged person has made return on the basis that the arm’s length provision applies),
* section 177 (when claim may be made or amended), and
* sections 181 to 184 (option to make claims in accordance with section 182 in some cases where actual provision relates to a security issued by one of the affected persons).
Subsection (2) has effect subject to—
* section 180 (closing trading stock and closing work in progress in a trade),
* sections 188 and 189 (effect of claims under this section on double taxation relief),
* Chapter 5 (provision, where liabilities of an affected person under securities issued by that person are guaranteed, for attribution to guarantor of things done by that affected person),
* section 447(5) and (6) of CTA 2009 (this Part generally does not affect how exchange gains or losses from loan relationships are accounted for), and
* section 694(8) and (9) of CTA 2009 (this Part generally does not affect how exchange gains or losses from derivative contracts are accounted for).
Claims under section 174 where actual provision relates to a security
A claim under section 174 may not be made if—
the participation condition (see section 148) would not be satisfied butfor section 161 or 162,
the actual provision is provision in relation to a security issued by oneof the affected persons (“the issuer”), and
a guarantee is provided in relation to the security by a person with whomthe issuer has a participatory relationship.
For the purposes of subsection (1), one person (“A”) has a “participatoryrelationship” with another (“B”) if—
one of A and B is directly or indirectly participating in the management,control or capital of the other, or
the same person or persons is or are directly or indirectly participatingin the management, control or capital of each of A and B.
In subsections (1)(b) and (4)(a) “security” includes securities notcreating or evidencing a charge on assets.
For the purposes of subsection (1)(b), any—
interest payable by a company on money advanced without the issue of asecurity for the advance, or
other consideration given by a company for the use of money so advanced,
is to be treated as if payable or given in respect of a security issued forthe advance by the company, and references to a security are to be readaccordingly.
The reference in subsection (1)(c) to a guarantee includes—
a reference to a surety, and

if the issuer is a company, a reference to any other relationship,arrangements, connection or understanding (whether formal or informal) suchthat the person making the loan to the issuer has a reasonable expectationthat in the event of a default by the issuer the person will be paid by, orout of the assets of, one or more companies.
Claims under section 174: advantaged person must have made return

A claim may not be made under section 174 unless a calculation has beenmade in the case of the advantaged person on the basis that the arm’s lengthprovision was made or imposed instead of the actual provision.
A claim made under section 174 must be consistent with the calculation madeon that basis in the case of the advantaged person.

For the purposes of subsections (1) and (2), a calculation is to be takento have been made in the case of the advantaged person on the basis that thearm’s length provision was made or imposed instead of the actual provision if(and only if)—
the calculations made for the purposes of any return by the advantagedperson have been made on that basis because of this Part, or
a relevant notice (see section 190) given to the advantaged person takesaccount of a determination in pursuance of this Part of an amount to bebrought into account for tax purposes on that basis.
Time for making, or amending, claim under section 174
A claim under section 174 can be made only in the period mentioned insubsection (2) or (3).
If a return has been made by the advantaged person on the basis mentionedin section 176(1), the period is the two years beginning with the day of themaking of the return.

If a relevant notice (see section 190) taking account of such adetermination as is mentioned in section 176(3)(b) has been given to theadvantaged person, the period is the two years beginning with the day on whichthat notice was given.
Subsection (5) applies if—
a claim under section 174 is made in relation to a return made on the basismentioned in section 176(1), and
a relevant notice taking account of such a determination as is mentioned insection 176(3)(b) is subsequently given to the advantaged person.

The disadvantaged person is entitled, within the period mentioned insubsection (3), to make any such amendment of the claim as may be appropriatein consequence of the determination contained in the relevant notice.
Subsections (1) and (5) have effect subject to section 186(3) (whichprovides for the extension of the period for making or amending a claim).
Meaning of “return” in sections 176 and 177
In sections 176 and 177 “return” means—
any return required to be made under TMA 1970 or under Schedule 18 to FA1998 for income tax or corporation tax purposes, or
any voluntary amendment of a return within paragraph (a).
In subsection (1)(b) “voluntary amendment” means—
an amendment under section 9ZA or 12ABA of TMA 1970 (amendment of personal,trustee or partnership return by taxpayer), or
an amendment under Schedule 18 to FA 1998 other than one made in responseto the giving of a relevant notice (see section 190).
Claims: special cases
Compensating payment if advantaged person is controlled foreigncompany
Subsection (2) applies if—
the actual provision is provision made or imposed in relation to acontrolled foreign company,

in determining for the purposes of Chapter 4 of Part 17 of ICTA the amountof that company’s chargeable profits for an accounting period, its profits andlosses are to be calculated in accordance with section 147(3) or (5) in thecase of that provision,
the whole of those chargeable profits are to be apportioned under section747(3) of ICTA to one or more companies resident in the United Kingdom, and
tax is chargeable under section 747(4) of ICTA in respect of the whole ofthose chargeable profits, as so apportioned to those companies.
Sections 174 to 178 have effect as if the controlled foreign company were aperson on whom a potential advantage in relation to United Kingdom taxationwere conferred by the actual provision.
In applying sections 174 to 178 in a case in which they apply because ofsubsection (2)—
references to the advantaged person in sections 176(3)(a) and (b) and177(2), (3) and (4)(b) include a reference to any of the companies mentionedin subsection (1)(c), and
references to corporation tax include a reference to tax chargeable undersection 747(4) of ICTA.
In this section—
* “controlled foreign company” has the same meaning as in Chapter 4 of Part 17 of ICTA, and
* “accounting period”, in relation to a controlled foreign company, has the same meaning as in that Chapter.
Application of section 174(2)(a) in relation to transfers of tradingstock etc
Section 174(2)(a) does not affect the credits to be brought into account bythe disadvantaged person in respect of—
closing trading stock, or
closing work in progress in a trade,
for accounting periods ending on or after the day given by subsection (2).
That day is the last day of the accounting period of the advantaged personin which the actual provision was made or imposed.
For the purposes of this section “trading stock”, in relation to any trade,has the meaning given by—
section 174 of ITTOIA 2005, or
section 163 of CTA 2009.
Alternative way of claiming if a security is involved
Section 182 applies to claims where actual provision relates to asecurity
Subsection (2) applies if—
both of the affected persons are companies, and
the actual provision is provision in relation to a security issued by oneof those companies.
A claim under section 174 may be made in accordance with section 182.
For the purposes of this Part, a “section 182 claim” is a claim undersection 174 made in accordance with section 182.
In subsections (1)(b) and (5)(a) “security” includes securities notcreating or evidencing a charge on assets.
For the purposes of subsection (1)(b), any—
interest payable by a company on money advanced without the issue of asecurity for the advance, or
other consideration given by a company for the use of money so advanced,
is to be treated as if payable or given in respect of a security issued forthe advance by the company, and references to a security are to be readaccordingly.
Making of section 182 claims
A section 182 claim may be made by—
the disadvantaged person, or
the advantaged person.
A section 182 claim made by the advantaged person is to be taken to be madeon behalf of the disadvantaged person.
A section 182 claim may be made before or after a calculation withinsection 176(1) has been made.
A section 182 claim must be made either—
at any time before the end of the period mentioned in section 177(2), or
within the period mentioned in section 177(3).
Subsection (4) has effect subject to section 186(3) (which provides for theextension of the period for making a claim).
Giving effect to section 182 claims
A section 182 claim is not a claim within paragraph 57 or 58 of Schedule 18to FA 1998 (company tax returns, assessments and related matters).
Accordingly, paragraph 59 of that Schedule (application of Schedule 1A toTMA 1970) has effect in relation to a section 182 claim.
If—
a section 182 claim is made before a calculation within section 176(1) hasbeen made,
such a calculation is subsequently made, and
the claim is not consistent with the calculation,
the affected persons are to be treated as if (instead of the claim actuallymade) a claim had been made that was consistent with the calculation.
All such adjustments are to be made (including by the making ofassessments) as are required to give effect to subsection (3).
Subsection (4) has effect despite any limit on the time within which anyadjustment may be made.
Amending a section 182 claim if it is followed by relevant notice
Subsection (2) applies if—
a section 182 claim is made,
a return is subsequently made by the advantaged person on the basismentioned in section 176(1), and
a relevant notice (see section 190) taking account of such a determinationas is mentioned in section 176(3)(b) is subsequently given to the advantagedperson.
If any amendment of the claim is appropriate in consequence of thedetermination contained in the relevant notice, the amendment may be made by—
the disadvantaged person, or
the advantaged person.
If an amendment under subsection (2) is made by the advantaged person it isto be taken to be made on behalf of the disadvantaged person.
Any amendment under subsection (2) must be made within the period mentionedin section 177(3).
Subsection (4) has effect subject to section 186(3) (which provides for theextension of the period for making an amendment).
Notification to persons who may be disadvantaged
Notice to potential claimants
Subsection (2) applies if—
a relevant notice (see section 190) is given to any person,
the notice, or anything contained in it, takes account of a transfer-pricing determination, and
it appears to an officer that there is a person (“DP”) who is or may be adisadvantaged person by reference to the subject-matter of the determination.
The officer must give to DP a notice containing particulars of thedetermination.
A contravention of subsection (2) does not affect the validity—
of the relevant notice, or
of any determination to which the notice relates.
For the purposes of this section, a person is a disadvantaged person byreference to the subject-matter of a transfer-pricing determination if (andonly if) the person—
is entitled, in consequence of the making of the determination, to make oramend a claim under section 174, or
will be entitled, because of section 212(3), to be a party to anyproceedings on an appeal relating to the determination.
In this section—
* “officer” means officer of Revenue and Customs, and
* “transfer-pricing determination” means a determination of an amount that is to be brought into account for tax purposes in respect of—
any assumption made under section 147(3) or (5), or
any advance-pricing-agreement assumptions (see section 222(6)).
Extending claim period if notice under section 185 not given or givenlate

If there is a contravention of section 185(2), the Commissioners mustconsider whether, as a result of the contravention, any person has beenprejudiced with respect to the making or amendment of a claim under section174.
Subsection (3) applies if—
there is a contravention of section 185(2), or
a notice required by section 185(2) is given after the relevant noticeconcerned.

The Commissioners may, if they think fit, treat the period for the makingor amendment of a claim under section 174 in the case concerned as extended bysuch further period as appears to them to be appropriate.
In this section “the Commissioners” means the Commissioners for HerMajesty’s Revenue and Customs.
Treatment of interest where claim made
Tax treatment if actual interest exceeds arm’s length interest
Subsection (6) applies if the following conditions are met.
Condition A is that interest is paid by any person under the actualprovision.
Condition B is that section 147(3) or (5) applies in relation to the actualprovision.
Condition C is—
that the amount (“ALINT”) of interest that would have been payable underthe arm’s length provision is less than the amount of interest paid under theactual provision, or
that there would not have been any interest payable under the arm’s lengthprovision (so that ALINT is nil).
Condition D is that the person receiving the interest paid under the actualprovision makes—
a claim under section 174, or
a section 182 claim.
The interest paid under the actual provision, so far as it exceeds ALINT—
is not to be regarded as chargeable under Chapter 2 of Part 4 of ITTOIA2005,
is not subject to the provisions of Part 15 of ITA 2007 (deduction ofincome tax at source), and
is not required to be brought into account under Part 5 of CTA 2009 (loanrelationships) as a non-trading credit.
Adjustment of double taxation relief where claim made
Double taxation relief by way of credit for foreign tax
Subsection (2) applies if—
a claim is made under section 174, and

the disadvantaged person (“DP”) is entitled on that claim to make acalculation, or to have an adjustment made, on the basis that the arm’s lengthprovision was made or imposed instead of the actual provision.
Assumptions A and B are to be made in DP’s case in relation to any creditfor foreign tax which DP has been, or may be, given—
under any double taxation arrangements, or
under section 18(1)(b) and (2) (relief under unilateral reliefarrangements).
Subsection (2) has effect subject to section 189(2).

Assumption A is that the foreign tax paid or payable by DP does not includeany amount of foreign tax which would not be or have become payable were it tobe assumed for the purposes of that tax that the arm’s length provision hadbeen made or imposed instead of the actual provision.

Assumption B is that the amount of DP’s relevant profits in respect ofwhich DP is given credit for foreign tax does not include the amount (if any)by which DP’s relevant profits are treated as reduced in accordance withsection 174.
If any adjustment is required to be made for the purpose of giving effectto any of the preceding provisions of this section—
it may be made by setting the amount of the adjustment against any reliefor repayment to which DP is entitled in pursuance of DP’s claim under section174, and
nothing in the Tax Acts limiting the time within which any assessment is tobe or may be made or amended prevents that adjustment from being so made.
In subsection (5) “DP’s relevant profits” means the profits arising to DPfrom the carrying on of the relevant activities (see section 216).
In this section—
* “double taxation arrangements” means arrangements that have effect under section 2(1) (double taxation relief by agreement with territories outside the United Kingdom), and
* “foreign tax” means—
any tax under the law of a territory outside the United Kingdom, or
any amount that, for the purposes of any double taxation arrangements, is tobe treated as if it were tax under the law of a territory outside the UnitedKingdom.
In determining for the purposes of this section whether a person is—
under any double taxation arrangements, or
under section 18(1)(b) and (2),
to be given credit for foreign tax, ignore any requirement that a claim ismade before such a credit is given.
Double taxation relief by way of deduction for foreign tax
Subsection (2) applies if—
a claim is made under section 174,

the disadvantaged person (“DP”) is entitled on that claim to make acalculation, or to have an adjustment made, on the basis that the arm’s lengthprovision was made or imposed instead of the actual provision,
the application of that basis in the calculation of DP’s profits or lossesfor any chargeable period involves a reduction in the amount of any income,and
that income is also income that is to be reduced in accordance with section112(1) (deduction for foreign tax where no credit allowed).
If this subsection applies—
the reduction mentioned in subsection (1)(c) is to be treated as madebefore any reduction under section 112(1), and

tax paid, in the place in which any income arises, on so much of thatincome as is represented by the amount of the reduction mentioned insubsection (1)(c) is to be disregarded for the purposes of section 112(1).
If any adjustment is required to be made for the purpose of giving effectto any of the preceding provisions of this section—
it may be made by setting the amount of the adjustment against any reliefor repayment to which DP is entitled in pursuance of DP’s claim under section174, and
nothing in the Tax Acts limiting the time within which any assessment is tobe or may be made or amended prevents that adjustment from being so made.
Interpretation of Chapter
Meaning of “relevant notice”
In this Chapter “relevant notice” means—
a closure notice under section 28A(1) of TMA 1970 in relation to an enquiryinto a return under section 8 or 8A of TMA 1970,
a closure notice under section 28B(1) of TMA 1970 in relation to an enquiryinto a partnership return,
a closure notice under paragraph 32 of Schedule 18 to FA 1998 in relationto an enquiry into a company tax return,
a notice under section 30B(1) of TMA 1970 amending a partnership return,
a notice of an assessment under section 29 of TMA 1970,
a notice of a discovery assessment under paragraph 41 of Schedule 18 to FA1998 (which includes a discovery assessment under that paragraph as applied byparagraph 52 of that Schedule), or
a notice of a discovery determination under paragraph 41 of Schedule 18 toFA 1998.
CHAPTER 5Position of guarantor of affected person’s liabilities under asecurity issued by the person
When sections 192 to 194 apply
Sections 192 to 194 apply if—
one of the affected persons (“the issuing company”) is a company that hasliabilities under a security issued by it,
those liabilities are to any extent the subject of a guarantee provided bya company (“the guarantor company”),

in calculating the profits and losses of the issuing company for taxpurposes, the amounts to be deducted in respect of interest or other amountspayable under the security are required to be reduced (whether or not to nil)under section 147(3) or (5), and
that reduction is required because of section 153.
In subsections (1)(a) and (3)(a) “security” includes securities notcreating or evidencing a charge on assets.
For the purposes of subsection (1)(a), any—
interest payable by a company on money advanced without the issue of asecurity for the advance, or
other consideration given by a company for the use of money so advanced,
is to be treated as if payable or given in respect of a security issued forthe advance by the company, and the reference in subsection (1)(a) to asecurity is to be read accordingly.
In subsection (1)(b) the reference to a guarantee includes—
a reference to a surety, and

a reference to any other relationship, arrangements, connection orunderstanding (whether formal or informal) such that the person making theloan to the issuing company has a reasonable expectation that in the event ofa default by the issuing company the person will be paid by, or out of theassets of, one or more companies.
In this Chapter—
* “the guarantor company” has the meaning given by subsection (1)(b),
* “the issuing company” has the meaning given by subsection (1)(a), and
* “the security” means the security mentioned in subsection (1)(a).
Attribution to guarantor company of things done by issuing company

On the making of a claim, the guarantor company is, to the extent of thereduction mentioned in section 191(1)(c), to be treated for all purposes ofthe Taxes Acts as if it (and not the issuing company)—
had issued the security,
owed the liabilities under it, and
had paid any interest or other amounts paid under it by the issuingcompany.
Subsection (1) is subject to subsection (3).
Where the issuing company’s liabilities under the security are the subjectof two or more guarantees (whether or not provided by the same person), TDmust not exceed TR, where—
* TD is the total of the amounts brought into account by the guarantor companies because of subsection (1), and
* TR is the total amount of the reductions within section 191(1)(c).
Provision about claims under subsection (1) is made by—
* section 193 (interaction between claims under subsection (1) and claims under section 174), and
* section 194 (general provision about claims under subsection (1)).
In subsection (1) “the Taxes Acts” has the meaning given by section 118(1)of TMA 1970.
In subsection (3) any reference to a guarantee includes—
a reference to a surety, and

a reference to any other relationship, arrangements, connection orunderstanding (whether formal or informal) such that the person making theloan to the issuing company has a reasonable expectation that in the event ofa default by the issuing company the person will be paid by, or out of theassets of, one or more companies.
Interaction between claims under sections 174 and 192(1)
In this section “the loan provision” means the actual provision made orimposed between—
the issuing company, and
another company (“the lending company”),
which is provision in relation to the security.
Subsections (3) and (4) apply if—
the guarantor company makes a claim under section 192(1), and
the lending company makes a claim under section 174 in relation to the loanprovision.

In determining the arm’s length provision for the purposes of section174(2)(a) in relation to the lending company’s claim, additional amounts areto be brought into account as credits corresponding to the debits that fall tobe brought into account by the guarantor company because of section 192(1).
If—
the lending company makes its claim under section 174 before the guarantorcompany makes its claim under section 192(1), and
the calculation on which the lending company’s claim is based does notcomply with subsection (3),
the guarantor company’s claim is to be disallowed.
Claims under section 192(1): general provisions
A claim under section 192(1) may be made—
by the guarantor company,
if there are two or more guarantor companies, by those companies actingtogether, or
by the issuing company.
A claim made under section 192(1) by the issuing company is to be taken tobe made on behalf of the guarantor company or companies.

Sections 175 to 177 apply in relation to a claim under section 192(1) madeby or on behalf of any person or persons as they apply in relation to a claimunder section 174 made by the disadvantaged person, but taking—
references in sections 176 and 177 to the advantaged person as referencesto the issuing company, and
the reference in section 177 to the disadvantaged person as a reference tothe guarantor company or companies.
CHAPTER 6Balancing payments
Qualifying conditions for purposes of section 196
Conditions A to D are “the qualifying conditions” for the purposes ofsection 196.
Condition A is that only one of the affected persons (“the advantagedperson”) is a person on whom a potential advantage in relation to UnitedKingdom taxation is conferred by the actual provision.

Condition B is that the other affected person (“the disadvantaged person”)is within the charge to income tax or corporation tax in respect of profitsarising from the relevant activities (see section 216).
Condition C is that—
a payment (the “balancing payment”) is made, or
two or more payments (the “balancing payments”) are made,
to the advantaged person by the disadvantaged person.
Condition D is that the sole or main reason for making that payment orthose payments is that section 147(3) or (5) applies.
Balancing payments between affected persons: no charge to, or relieffrom, tax
If each of the qualifying conditions (see section 195) is met, subsection(2) applies—
to the balancing payment if, or so far as, its amount does not exceed theavailable compensating adjustment, or
to the balancing payments if, or so far as, their total amount does notexceed the available compensating adjustment.
Any payment to which this subsection applies—
is not to be taken into account in calculating profits or losses of eitherof the affected persons for the purposes of income tax or corporation tax, and
is not for any purpose of the Corporation Tax Acts to be regarded as adistribution.
In subsection (1) “the available compensating adjustment” means thedifference between PL1 and PL2 where—
* PL1 is the profits and losses of the disadvantaged person calculated for tax purposes on the basis of the actual provision, and
* PL2 is the profits and losses of the disadvantaged person as (or as they would be) calculated for tax purposes on a claim under section 174.
For the purposes of subsection (3), take PL1 or PL2—
as a positive amount if it is an amount of profits, and
as a negative amount if it is an amount of losses.
In this section, the following expressions have the meaning given bysection 195—
* “the balancing payment” and “the balancing payments”, and
* “the disadvantaged person”.
Qualifying conditions for purposes of section 198
Conditions A to F are the qualifying conditions for the purposes of section198.
Condition A is that one of the affected persons (“the issuing company”) isa company that has liabilities under a security issued by it.
Condition B is that those liabilities are to any extent the subject of aguarantee provided by a company (“the guarantor company”).

Condition C is that, in calculating the profits and losses of the issuingcompany for tax purposes, the amounts to be deducted in respect of interest orother amounts payable under the security are required to be reduced (whetheror not to nil) under section 147(3) or (5).
Condition D is that that reduction is required because of section 153.
Condition E is that—
a payment (the “balancing payment”) is made, or
two or more payments (the “balancing payments”) are made,
by the guarantor company to the issuing company.
Condition F is that the sole or main reasons for making that payment orthose payments are—
that section 147(3) or (5) applies because of section 153, or
that sections 192 to 194 apply.
In subsections (2) and (9)(a) “security” includes securities not creatingor evidencing a charge on assets.
For the purposes of subsection (2), any—
interest payable by a company on money advanced without the issue of asecurity for the advance, or
other consideration given by a company for the use of money so advanced,
is to be treated as if payable or given in respect of a security issued forthe advance by the company, and the reference in subsection (2) to a securityis to be read accordingly.
In subsection (3) the reference to a guarantee includes—
a reference to a surety, and

a reference to any other relationship, arrangements, connection orunderstanding (whether formal or informal) such that the person making theloan to the issuing company has a reasonable expectation that in the event ofa default by the issuing company the person will be paid by, or out of theassets of, one or more companies.
Balancing payments by guarantor to issuer: no charge to, or relieffrom, tax

If each of the qualifying conditions (see section 197) is met, subsection(2) applies to the balancing payments made by all of the guarantor companiesif, or so far as, the total amount of those payments does not exceed the totalamount of the reductions within section 197(4).
Payments to which this subsection applies—
are not to be taken into account in calculating for the purposes ofcorporation tax the profits or losses of the guarantor company or companies orthe issuing company, and
are not for any purpose of the Corporation Tax Acts to be regarded asdistributions.
In this section, the following expressions have the meaning given bysection 197—
* “the balancing payments”,
* “the guarantor company”, and
* “the issuing company”.
Pre-conditions for making election under section 200
Conditions A to E are the pre-conditions for the purposes of section 200.
Condition A is that both of the affected persons are companies.
Condition B is that only one of the affected persons (“the advantagedperson”) is a person on whom a potential advantage in relation to UnitedKingdom taxation is conferred by the actual provision.

Condition C is that the other affected person (“the disadvantaged person”)is within the charge to income tax or corporation tax in respect of profitsarising from the relevant activities (see section 216).
Condition D is that the actual provision is provision in relation to asecurity (the “relevant security”).
Condition E is that the capital market condition is met (see section 204).
In subsections (5) and (8)(a) “security” includes securities not creatingor evidencing a charge on assets.
For the purposes of subsection (5), any—
interest payable by a company on money advanced without the issue of asecurity for the advance, or
other consideration given by a company for the use of money so advanced,
is to be treated as if payable or given in respect of a security issued forthe advance by the company, and the reference in subsection (5) to a securityis to be read accordingly.
Election to pay tax rather than make balancing payments
If each of the pre-conditions (see section 199) is met, the disadvantagedperson may make an election—

to make no balancing payment within section 196 to the advantaged person inconnection with section 147(3) or (5) applying because of section 152 inrelation to the relevant security in a chargeable period, but

instead, to undertake sole responsibility for discharging the advantagedperson’s liability to tax for that period so far as resulting from section147(3) or (5) applying because of section 152 in relation to the relevantsecurity.
Section 203 contains provision about the making and effect of electionsunder this section.
In this section, the following expressions have the meaning given bysection 199—
* “the advantaged person”,
* “the disadvantaged person”, and
* “the relevant security”.
Pre-conditions for making election under section 202
Conditions A to E are the pre-conditions for the purposes of section 202.
Condition A is that both of the affected persons are companies.
Condition B is that only one of the affected persons (“the advantagedperson”) is a person on whom a potential advantage in relation to UnitedKingdom taxation is conferred by the actual provision.

Condition C is that the other affected person (“the disadvantaged person”)is within the charge to income tax or corporation tax in respect of profitsarising from the relevant activities (see section 216).
Condition D is that the actual provision is made or imposed by means of aseries of transactions which include—
the issuing of a security (“the relevant security”) by one of the affectedpersons (“the issuing company”), and
the provision of a guarantee by the other affected person.
Condition E is that the capital market condition is met (see section 204).
In subsections (5) and (8)(a) “security” includes securities not creatingor evidencing a charge on assets.
For the purposes of subsection (5), any—
interest payable by a company on money advanced without the issue of asecurity for the advance, or
other consideration given by a company for the use of money so advanced,
is to be treated as if payable or given in respect of a security issued forthe advance by the company, and the reference in subsection (5) to a securityis to be read accordingly.
In subsection (5) the reference to a guarantee includes—
a reference to a surety, and

a reference to any other relationship, arrangements, connection orunderstanding (whether formal or informal) such that the person making theloan to the issuing company has a reasonable expectation that in the event ofa default by the issuing company the person will be paid by, or out of theassets of, one or more companies.
Election, in guarantee case, to pay tax rather than make balancingpayments
If each of the pre-conditions (see section 201) is met, the disadvantagedperson may make an election—

to make no balancing payment within section 198 to the advantaged person inconnection with section 147(3) or (5) applying because of section 153 inrelation to the relevant security in a chargeable period, but

instead, to undertake sole responsibility for discharging the advantagedperson’s liability to tax for that period so far as resulting from section147(3) or (5) applying because of section 153 in relation to the relevantsecurity.
Section 203 contains provision about the making and effect of electionsunder this section.
In this section, the following expressions have the meaning given bysection 201—
* “the advantaged person”,
* “the disadvantaged person”, and
* “the relevant security”.
Elections under section 200 or 202
In this section “election” means election under section 200 or 202.
An election must be made by being included (whether by amendment orotherwise) in the disadvantaged person’s company tax return for the chargeableperiod in which the relevant security is issued.
An election is irrevocable.
An election has effect in relation to each of the affected persons for thechargeable period in which the relevant security is issued and all subsequentchargeable periods.
An election is of no effect if the Commissioners for Her Majesty’s Revenueand Customs give the disadvantaged person a notice refusing to accept theelection.
A notice under subsection (5) may be given only after a notice of enquiryin respect of the company tax return containing the election has been given tothe disadvantaged person.
(Paragraph 24 of Schedule 18 to FA 1998 makes provision about notices ofenquiry in respect of company tax returns.)
If an election has effect in relation to an accounting period of theadvantaged person, the tax mentioned in subsection (1)(b) of the section underwhich the election is made—
is recoverable from the disadvantaged person as if it were an amount ofcorporation tax due and owing from that person, and
is not recoverable from the advantaged person.
In this section—
* “the advantaged person”, “the disadvantaged person” and “the relevant security”—
in relation to an election under section 200, have the meaning given bysection 199, and
in relation to an election under section 202, have the meaning given bysection 201, and
* “company tax return” means the return required to be delivered pursuant to a notice under paragraph 3 of Schedule 18 to FA 1998, as read with paragraph 4 of that Schedule.

For the purposes of subsections (2) and (4), if the relevant security wasissued in a chargeable period beginning before 1st April 2004 it is to betreated as if it had been issued in the chargeable period beginning on thatdate.
Meaning of “capital market condition” in sections 199 and 201
For the purposes of section 199(6) or 201(6), the capital market conditionis met if—
the actual provision forms part of a capital market arrangement,
the capital market arrangement involves the issue of a capital marketinvestment,
the securities that represent the capital market investment are issuedwholly or mainly to independent persons, and
the total value of the capital market investments made under the capitalmarket arrangement is at least £50 million.
In this section—
* “capital market arrangement” has the same meaning as in section 72B(1) of the Insolvency Act 1986 (see paragraph 1 of Schedule 2A to that Act),
* “capital market investment” has the same meaning as in section 72B(1) of the Insolvency Act 1986 (see paragraphs 2 and 3 of Schedule 2A to that Act), and
* “independent person” means a person—
who is not the disadvantaged person, and
who does not have a participatory relationship with either of the affectedpersons.
In subsection (2) “the disadvantaged person”—
for the purposes of the application of this section in relation to section199(6) has the meaning given by section 199(4), and
for the purposes of the application of this section in relation to section201(6) has the meaning given by section 201(4).
For the purposes of subsection (2), a person (“A”) who is a company has a“participatory relationship” with one of the affected persons (“B”) if—
one of A and B is directly or indirectly participating in the management,control or capital of the other, or
the same person or persons is or are directly or indirectly participatingin the management, control or capital of each of A and B.
CHAPTER 7Oil-related ring-fence trades
Provision made or imposed between ring-fence trade and otheractivities
Subsections (2) to (4) apply if—
a person carries on an oil-related ring-fence trade (see section 206), and
any provision is made or imposed by the person as between—
the oil-related ring-fence trade, and
any other activities carried on by the person.
Chapters 1 and 3 to 6 (read in accordance with Chapters 2 and 8) apply inrelation to the provision as if—
the oil-related ring-fence trade, and the person’s other activities, werecarried on by two different persons,
the provision were made or imposed as between those two persons by means ofa transaction,
those two persons were both controlled by the same person at the time whenthe provision was made or imposed, and
a potential advantage in relation to United Kingdom taxation were conferredby the provision on each of those two persons.
Subsection (2) has effect subject to subsection (4).
Chapters 1 and 3 to 6 apply in relation to the provision only if the effectof their applying is—
that a larger amount is taken for tax purposes to be the amount of theprofits of the oil-related ring-fence trade for any chargeable period, or
that a smaller amount (including nil) is taken for tax purposes to be theamount for any chargeable period of any losses of the oil-related ring-fencetrade.
In subsection (4)(a), the reference to a larger amount includes, if therewould not otherwise have been profits, an amount of more than nil.
Meaning of “oil-related ring-fence trade” in sections 205 and 218
This section has effect for the interpretation of—
section 205, and
in Part 5, section 218(2)(f).
Activities carried on by a person are an “oil-related ring-fence trade”carried on by that person if subsection (3) or (4) applies to the activities.
This subsection applies to the activities if—
they are carried on by the person as part of a trade, and

in accordance with section 16(1) of ITTOIA 2005 or section 279 of CTA 2010(oil-related activities), they are treated for any tax purposes as a separatetrade distinct from all other activities carried on by the person as part ofthe trade.
This subsection applies to the activities if—
they are carried on by the person as a trade, and

in accordance with section 16(1) of ITTOIA 2005 or section 279 of CTA 2010they would, if the person did carry on any other activities as part of thetrade, be treated for any tax purposes as a separate trade distinct from allother activities carried on by the person as part of the trade.
CHAPTER 8Supplementary provisions and interpretation of Part
Unit trusts
Application of Part to unit trusts
This Part has effect as follows.
As if a unit trust scheme were a company that is a body corporate.
As if the rights of the unit holders under a unit trust scheme were sharesin the company that the scheme is deemed to be.
As if rights and powers of a person in the capacity of a person entitled toact for the purposes of a unit trust scheme were rights and powers of thescheme.
As if provision made or imposed as between—
a person in the capacity of a person entitled to act for the purposes of aunit trust scheme, and
another person,
were made or imposed as between the scheme and that other person.
Determinations requiring Commissioners’ sanction
The determinations which require the Commissioners’ sanction
A determination requires the Commissioners’ sanction if it—
is a transfer-pricing determination made for any of the specified purposes,and
is not excepted by section 209 from the requirement for the Commissioners’sanction.
In subsection (1) “transfer-pricing determination” means a determination ofan amount to be brought into account for tax purposes in respect of anyassumption made under section 147(3) or (5).
For the purposes of subsection (1), each of the following is a specifiedpurpose—
the giving of a closure notice under section 28A(1) of TMA 1970 in relationto an enquiry into a return under section 8 or 8A of TMA 1970,
the giving of a closure notice under section 28B(1) of TMA 1970 in relationto an enquiry into a partnership return,
the giving of a closure notice under paragraph 32 of Schedule 18 to FA 1998in relation to an enquiry into a company tax return,
the giving of a notice under section 30B(1) of TMA 1970 amending apartnership return,
the making of an assessment under section 29 of TMA 1970,
the making of a discovery assessment under paragraph 41 of Schedule 18 toFA 1998 (which includes a discovery assessment under that paragraph as appliedby paragraph 52 of that Schedule), and
the making of a discovery determination under paragraph 41 of Schedule 18to FA 1998.
In this section “the Commissioners” means the Commissioners for HerMajesty’s Revenue and Customs.
Determinations exempt from requirement for Commissioners’ sanction
A transfer-pricing determination made for a purpose specified in section208(3) (“the specified purpose”) does not require the Commissioners’ sanctionif—
an agreement about the matters to which the determination relates has beenmade between an officer and the person in whose case the determination ismade,
the agreement is in force at the relevant time, and
the matters to which the agreement relates include the amount determined bythe transfer-pricing determination.
For the purposes of subsection (1)(b)—
if the specified purpose is within section 208(3)(a) to (d), “the relevanttime” is when the notice is given,
if the specified purpose is within section 208(3)(e) or (f), “the relevanttime” is when any notice of the assessment is given, and
if the specified purpose is within section 208(3)(g), “the relevant time”is when any notice of the discovery determination is given.
For the purposes of subsection (1)(b), an agreement made between an officerand any person in relation to any matter is “in force” at any time if (andonly if)—
the agreement is one that has been made or confirmed in writing,
that time is after the end of the cooling-off period, and
the person has not, before the end of the cooling-off period, served anotice on an officer stating that the person is repudiating or resiling fromthe agreement.
In subsection (3) “the cooling-off period” means—
if the agreement is made in writing, the 30 days beginning with the daywhen the agreement is made, and
in any other case, the 30 days beginning with the day when the agreement isconfirmed in writing.
For the purposes of subsections (3) and (4), an agreement made between anofficer and any person is “confirmed in writing” if an officer serves on theperson a notice in writing—
stating that the agreement has been made, and
setting out the terms of the agreement.
In this section—
* “the Commissioners” means the Commissioners for Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs,
* “officer” means officer of Revenue and Customs, and
* “transfer-pricing determination” has the meaning given by section 208(2).
The requirement for the Commissioners’ sanction

Subsection (2) applies in relation to a transfer-pricing determination madefor a purpose specified in section 208(3)(a) to (d) if, under section 208(1),the determination requires the Commissioners’ sanction.
If the closure notice, or notice under section 30B(1) of TMA 1970, is givento a person—
without the determination, so far as it is taken into account in thenotice, having been approved by the Commissioners, or
without a copy of the Commissioners’ approval having been served on theperson at or before the time when the notice is given to the person,
the notice has effect as if given in the terms (if any) in which it would havebeen given had the determination not been taken into account.

Subsection (4) applies in relation to a transfer-pricing determination madefor a purpose specified in section 208(3)(e) to (g) if, under section 208(1),the transfer-pricing determination requires the Commissioners’ sanction.
If notice of the assessment, or notice of the discovery determination, isgiven to a person—
without the transfer-pricing determination, so far as it is taken intoaccount in the assessment or discovery determination, having been approved bythe Commissioners, or
without a copy of the Commissioners’ approval having been served on theperson at or before the time when the notice is given to the person,

the assessment or discovery determination has effect as if made (and notified)in the terms (if any) in which it would have been made had the transfer-pricing determination not been taken into account.
For the purposes of subsections (2) and (4), the Commissioners’ approval ofa transfer-pricing determination requiring their sanction—
must be given specifically in relation to the case concerned and must applyto the amount determined, but
subject to that, may be given by the Commissioners (either before or afterthe determination is made) in any such form or manner as the Commissioners maydetermine.
In this section “the Commissioners” means the Commissioners for HerMajesty’s Revenue and Customs.
Restriction of right to appeal against Commissioners’ approval
In subsection (2)—
* “appeal” means an appeal by virtue of any provision of—
TMA 1970, or
Schedule 18 to FA 1998 (company tax returns and related matters), and
* “approved determination” means a determination that, for the purposes of section 210(2) or (4), has been approved by the Commissioners.
The matters that may be questioned on so much of an appeal as relates to anapproved determination do not include the Commissioners’ approval.
Subsection (2) does not apply so far as the grounds for questioning theapproval are the same as the grounds for questioning the determination.
In this section “the Commissioners” means the Commissioners for HerMajesty’s Revenue and Customs.
Appeals
Appeals
The appeals within this subsection are—
an appeal under section 31 of, or Schedule 1A to, TMA 1970,
an appeal under paragraph 34(3) of Schedule 18 to FA 1998 against anamendment of a company’s return, and
an appeal under paragraph 48 of that Schedule against a discoveryassessment or a discovery determination.
Subsection (3) applies so far as the question in dispute on an appealwithin subsection (1)—
is or involves a determination of whether this Part has effect, and

relates to any provision made or imposed as between two persons each ofwhom is within the charge to income tax or corporation tax in respect ofprofits arising from the relevant activities (see section 216).
If this subsection applies—
each of the persons as between whom the actual provision was made orimposed is entitled to be a party in any proceedings,
the tribunal is to determine the question separately from any otherquestion in the proceedings, and
the tribunal’s determination on the question has effect as if made in anappeal to which each of those persons was a party.
In subsection (1)(c)—

* “discovery assessment” means a discovery assessment under paragraph 41 of Schedule 18 to FA 1998 (which includes a discovery assessment under that paragraph as applied by paragraph 52 that Schedule), and
* “discovery determination” means a discovery determination under paragraph 41 of that Schedule.
Effect of Part on capital allowances and chargeable gains
Capital allowances
Nothing in this Part is to be read as affecting the calculation of theamount of any capital allowance or balancing charge made under CAA 2001.
Subsection (1) does not apply in relation to claims under section 174.
Chargeable gains
Nothing in this Part is to be read as affecting the calculation inaccordance with TCGA 1992 of the amount of any chargeable gain or allowableloss.

Nothing in this Part requires the profits and losses of any person to becalculated for tax purposes as if, in the person’s case, instead of income orlosses to be brought into account in connection with the taxation of income,there were gains or losses to be brought into account in accordance with TCGA1992.
Subsections (1) and (2) do not apply in relation to claims under section174.
Adjustments
Manner of making adjustments to give effect to Part
Any adjustments required to be made under this Part may be made by way ofdischarge or repayment of tax, by the modification of any assessment orotherwise.
Definitions
Meaning of “the relevant activities”
In this Part “the relevant activities”, in relation to a person (“A”) whois one of the persons as between whom any provision is made or imposed, meansactivities that—
are within subsection (2), and
are not within subsection (3).
The activities within this subsection are those of A’s activities thatcomprise the activities in the course of which, or with respect to which, thatprovision is made or imposed.
The activities within this subsection are any of A’s activities carried on—
separately from the activities mentioned in subsection (2), or
for the purposes of a different part of A’s business.
Meaning of “control” and “firm”
References in this Part to a person controlling a body corporate or firmare to be read in accordance with section 1124 of CTA 2010.
Subsection (1) has effect subject to subsection (4) and section 205(2).
Subsection (4) applies if—
the actual provision is made or imposed by or in relation to a sale of oil,
the oil sold is oil which has been, or is to be, extracted under rightsexercisable by a company (“the producer”) which, although it may be theseller, is not the buyer, and

at the time of the completion of the sale or when possession of the oilpasses, whichever is the earlier, at least 20% of the producer’s ordinaryshare capital is owned directly or indirectly by one or more of the buyer andthe companies (if any) that are linked to the buyer.
If this subsection applies, this Part has effect in relation to the actualprovision as if—
the buyer and the seller, and
the producer, if it is not the seller,
were all controlled by the same person at the time of the making or impositionof the actual provision.
For the purposes of subsection (3)(c), two companies are “linked” if—
one is under the control of the other, or
both are under the control of the same person or persons.
For the purposes of subsection (3)—
any question whether ordinary share capital is owned directly or indirectlyby a company is to be decided as for Chapter 3 of Part 24 of CTA 2010, and
rights to extract oil are to be taken to be exercisable by a company evenif they are exercisable by that company only jointly with another company ortwo or more other companies.
In this section “oil” includes any mineral oil or relative hydrocarbon oil,as well as natural gas.
In this Part persons carrying on a trade, profession or other business inpartnership are referred to collectively as a “firm”.
Part 5Advance pricing agreements
Meaning of “advance pricing agreement”
In this Part “advance pricing agreement” means a written agreement that—
is made by the Commissioners with any person (“A”) as a consequence of anapplication by A under section 223,
relates to one or more of the matters mentioned in subsection (2), and
declares that it is an agreement made for the purposes of this section.
Those matters are—
if A is not a company, the attribution of income to a branch or agencythrough which A has been carrying on a trade in the United Kingdom or isproposing to carry on a trade in the United Kingdom,
if A is a company, the attribution of income to a permanent establishmentthrough which A has been carrying on a trade in the United Kingdom or isproposing to carry on a trade in the United Kingdom,
the attribution of income to any permanent establishment of A’s, whereversituated, through which A has been carrying on, or is proposing to carry on,any business,
the extent to which income that has arisen or may arise to A is to be takenfor any purpose to be income arising in a country or territory outside theUnited Kingdom,
the treatment for tax purposes of any provision made or imposed, whetherbefore or after the date of the agreement, as between A and any associate (seesection 219) of A’s, and

the treatment for tax purposes of any provision made or imposed, whetherbefore or after the date of the agreement, as between an oil-related ring-fence trade carried on by A (see section 206) and any other activities carriedon by A.
Meaning of “associate” in section 218(2)(e)
This section applies for the purposes of section 218(2)(e).
Two persons are associates in relation to provision made or imposed asbetween them if at the time of the making or imposition of the provision—
one of them is directly or indirectly participating in the management,control or capital of the other, or
the same person or persons is or are directly or indirectly participatingin the management, control or capital of each of the two persons.

Two persons are also associates in relation to any provision if section217(4) (which applies to provision made or imposed in connection with sales ofoil) requires the persons to be treated as controlled by the same person atthe time of the making or imposition of that provision.

For the interpretation of subsection (2), see sections 157(1), 158(4),159(1) and 160(1) (which have the effect that references in subsection (2) todirect or indirect participation are to be read in accordance with provisionsof Chapter 2 of Part 4).
Effect of agreement on party to it
Subsection (2) applies if a chargeable period is one to which an advancepricing agreement relates.

The Tax Acts have effect in relation to the chargeable period as if, in thecase of the person with whom the Commissioners made the agreement, questionsrelating to the matters mentioned in section 218(2) are to be determined—
in accordance with the agreement, and
without reference to the provisions in accordance with which they wouldotherwise be determined.
Subsection (2) is subject to—
* subsections (4) and (5), and
* section 221.
A question is to be determined as mentioned in subsection (2) only so faras the agreement provides for the question to be determined in that way.
In the case of so much of a question as—
relates to any matter mentioned in paragraph (e) or (f) of section 218(2),and
is not comprised in a question that relates to a matter within anotherparagraph of section 218(2),
reference to a provision is capable of being excluded under subsection (2) byan advance pricing agreement only if the provision is in Part 4.
Effect of revocation of agreement or breach of its conditions
An advance pricing agreement does not have effect in accordance withsection 220(2) in relation to any determination of a question if any ofconditions A, B and C is met.
Condition A is that a time to which the question relates is after a time asfrom which an officer has revoked the agreement in accordance with theagreement’s terms.
Condition B is that the question relates to a time after, or in relation towhich, there has been a failure by a party to the agreement to comply with asignificant provision of the agreement.
Condition C is that the question relates to a matter as respects which akey condition has not been met or is no longer met.

A provision of the agreement is “significant” for the purposes ofsubsection (3) if compliance with that provision is, under the terms of theagreement, to be a condition of the agreement’s having effect.
Any other condition that, under the terms of the agreement, is to be acondition of the agreement’s having effect is a “key condition” for thepurposes of subsection (4).
Effect of agreement on non-parties
Subsections (2), (5) and (6) apply if—
an advance pricing agreement has effect in relation to any provision (“theactual provision”) made or imposed as between any person (“A”) and another(“B”), and

section 220(2) has the effect in A’s case of requiring a question relatingto the actual provision to be determined in accordance with the agreementrather than by reference to rules which would otherwise be applicable becauseof Part 4.

The provisions mentioned in subsection (3) have effect in B’s case on theassumption that any question within subsection (4) is to be determined, to thesame extent as in A’s case, by reference to the agreement.
The provisions are—
* sections 174 to 178 (transfer pricing: claim by disadvantaged person), and
* sections 188 and 189 (transfer pricing: adjustment of double taxation relief if claim made).
The questions are—
whether A is a person on whom a potential advantage in relation to UnitedKingdom taxation is conferred by the actual provision, and
what constitutes the arm’s length provision in relation to the actualprovision.
Subsection (2) has effect subject to any advance pricing agreement madebetween the Commissioners and B.

Any assumptions to be made because of the agreement are “advance-pricing-agreement assumptions” for the purposes of paragraph (b) of the definition insection 185(5) of “transfer-pricing determination”.
Application for agreement
For the purposes of section 218(1)(a), an application by a person (“A”) isan application under this section if it complies with subsections (2) to (5).

It must be an application to the Commissioners for the clarification byagreement of the effect in A’s case of provisions by reference to whichquestions relating to any one or more of the matters mentioned in section218(2) are to be, or might be, determined.
It must set out A’s understanding of what would in A’s case be the effect,in the absence of any agreement, of the provisions in relation to whichclarification is sought.
It must set out the respects in which it appears to A that clarification isrequired in relation to those provisions.
It must set out how A proposes that matters should be clarified in a mannerconsistent with the understanding mentioned in subsection (3).
Provision in agreement about years ended or begun before agreement made
An advance pricing agreement may contain provision relating to chargeableperiods ending before the agreement is made, subject to subsection (2).
An advance pricing agreement may not contain provision relating tochargeable periods ending before 27 July 1999.
If an advance pricing agreement—
relates to a chargeable period beginning or ending before the agreement ismade, and
provides for the manner in which adjustments are to be made for taxpurposes in consequence of the agreement,
the adjustments are to be made for those purposes in the manner provided forin the agreement.
Modification and revocation of agreement
Subsection (2) applies if an advance pricing agreement provides for themodification, or revocation, of the agreement—
by the Commissioners, or
by an officer.
The agreement may provide for the modification or revocation to take effectas from such time as the Commissioners or officer may determine.
A time determined under subsection (2) may be (but need not be) a timebefore the modification is made or the agreement is revoked.
Annulment of agreement for misrepresentation
Subsection (6) applies if each of conditions A to D is met.
Condition A is that the Commissioners and any person (“A”) have at any timepurported to enter into an advance pricing agreement.
Condition B is that, before that time, A fraudulently or negligentlyprovided the Commissioners with information which was false or misleading.
Condition C is that the information was so provided—
for or in connection with the application to the Commissioners for themaking of the agreement, or
otherwise in connection with the preparation of the agreement.
Condition D is that the Commissioners have notified A that the agreement isnullified by reason of the misrepresentation.
The agreement is to be treated as never made.
Penalty for misrepresentation in connection with agreement
A person is liable to a penalty of not more than £10,000 if the personfraudulently or negligently makes a false or misleading statement to theCommissioners or an officer—
for or in connection with any application to the Commissioners for them toenter into an advance pricing agreement, or
otherwise in connection with the preparation of an advance pricingagreement.
Party to agreement: duty to provide information
A party to an advance pricing agreement must provide the Commissioners fromtime to time with all reports and other information that the party may berequired to provide—
under the agreement, or
as a result of a request made by an officer in accordance with theagreement.
Modifications of agreement for double taxation purposes
Subsection (2) applies if a mutual agreement made under and for thepurposes of any double taxation arrangements is not consistent with the termsof an advance pricing agreement.

The Commissioners must ensure that the advance pricing agreement ismodified so far as may be necessary for enabling effect to be given to themutual agreement in relation to the subject-matter of the advance pricingagreement.
The Commissioners may comply with subsection (2) by exercising powersconferred on them by the advance pricing agreement or otherwise.
In this section “double taxation arrangements” means arrangements that haveeffect under section 2(1) (double taxation relief by agreement withterritories outside the United Kingdom).
Interpretation of Part: meaning of “Commissioners” and “officer”
In this Part—
* “the Commissioners” means the Commissioners for Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs, and
* “officer” means an officer of Revenue and Customs.
Part 6Tax arbitrage
Introduction
Overview

This Part provides for the service on companies of two kinds of notice, asa result of which they must calculate or recalculate their income orchargeable gains or liability to corporation tax less advantageously.
Sections 232 to 248 deal with the first kind of notice (“deductionnotices”).
In particular—
see sections 232 to 235 for provisions about the service of deductionnotices,
see sections 236 to 242 for the kinds of schemes (“deduction schemes”)involved, and
see sections 243 to 248 for the consequences of such notices.
Sections 249 to 254 deal with the second kind of notice (“receiptnotices”).
In particular—
see sections 249 to 253 for provisions about the service of receiptnotices, and
see section 254 for their consequences.
Sections 255 to 257 contain general provisions about both kinds of notice.
For the meaning of “scheme” etc, see section 258 (schemes and series oftransactions).
Deduction notices
Deduction notices
An officer of Revenue and Customs may give a company a notice under thissection if—
the company is within the charge to corporation tax, and
the officer considers on reasonable grounds that each of the deductionscheme conditions is or may be met in relation to a transaction to which thecompany is party.
In this Part—
a notice under this section is referred to as a “deduction notice”, and
“the deduction scheme conditions” means the conditions specified in section233.
For the consequences of a deduction notice, see section 243.
The deduction scheme conditions
This section sets out the deduction scheme conditions.
Deduction scheme condition A is that the transaction to which the companyis party forms part of a scheme that is a deduction scheme for the purposes ofthis Part (see sections 236 to 242).
Deduction scheme condition B is that the scheme is such that forcorporation tax purposes the company—
is in a position to claim, or has claimed, an amount by way of deduction inrespect of the transaction, or
is in a position to set off, or has set off, an amount relating to thetransaction against profits in an accounting period.
Deduction scheme condition C is that the main purpose of the scheme, or oneof its main purposes, is to achieve a UK tax advantage for the company.
Deduction scheme condition D is that the amount of the UK tax advantage ismore than minimal.
Schemes achieving UK tax advantage for a company
For the purposes of section 233, a scheme achieves a UK tax advantage for acompany if, in consequence of the scheme, the company is in a position toobtain, or has obtained—
a relief or increased relief from corporation tax,
a repayment or increased repayment of corporation tax, or
the avoidance or reduction of a charge to corporation tax.

In subsection (1)(a) “relief from corporation tax” includes a tax creditunder section 1109 of CTA 2010 (tax credits for certain recipients ofqualifying distributions) for the purposes of corporation tax.
For the purposes of subsection (1)(c) avoidance or reduction may, inparticular, be effected—
by receipts accruing in such a way that the recipient does not pay or beartax on them, or
by a deduction in calculating profits or gains.
Further provisions about deduction notices
A deduction notice must specify the transaction in relation to which theofficer of Revenue and Customs considers that each of the deduction schemeconditions is or may be met.
A deduction notice must specify the accounting period in relation to whichthe officer considers that deduction scheme condition B is or may be met inrelation to the transaction.

A deduction notice must inform the company to which it is given that, as aresult of the service of the notice, section 243(2) to (6) (consequences of adeduction notice) will apply if each of the deduction scheme conditions is metin relation to the transaction.
A deduction notice may relate to two or more transactions.
Deduction schemes
Schemes involving hybrid entities
A scheme is a deduction scheme if a party to a transaction forming part ofthe scheme meets conditions A and B.
Condition A is that the party is regarded as being a person under the taxlaw of any territory.

Condition B is that the party’s profits or gains are treated, for thepurposes of a relevant tax imposed under the law of any territory, as theprofits or gains of a person or persons other than the person mentioned incondition A.
Condition B is not met just because the party’s profits or gains aresubject to a rule that—
is similar to that in section 747(3) of ICTA (imputation of chargeableprofits of controlled foreign company), and
has effect under the tax law of any territory outside the United Kingdom.
For the purposes of this section, the following are relevant taxes—
income tax,
corporation tax, and
any tax of a similar character to income tax or corporation tax that isimposed by the law of a territory outside the United Kingdom.
Instruments of alterable character
A scheme is a deduction scheme if one of the parties to the scheme is partyto an instrument within subsection (2).
An instrument is within this subsection if under the law of a particularterritory any party to the instrument may alter its tax characteristics.

The reference to altering an instrument’s tax characteristics is to makingan alteration which, under the law of a particular territory, has the effectof determining, for the tax purposes of that territory, whether the instrumentis taken into account as giving rise—
to income,
to capital, or
to neither.
An instrument is taken into account as giving rise to capital if any gainon the disposal of the instrument—
would be a chargeable gain, or
would be such a gain if the person making the disposal were UK resident.
Shares subject to conversion
A scheme is a deduction scheme if it includes—
a company issuing shares subject to conversion, or
such an amendment of rights attaching to shares issued by a company thatthe shares become shares subject to conversion.
For the purposes of subsection (1)(a) a company’s shares are shares subjectto conversion if conditions A and B are met.
For the purposes of subsection (1)(b) a company’s shares are shares subjectto conversion if conditions A and C are met.

Condition A is that the rights attached to the shares include provision asa result of which a holder of such shares is entitled, on the occurrence of anevent, to acquire securities in a company by conversion or exchange.
Condition B is that at the time when the shares are issued the companycould reasonably expect that event to occur.
Condition C is that at the time when the rights attaching to the shares areamended as described in subsection (1)(b) the company could reasonably expectthat event to occur.
Securities subject to conversion
A scheme is a deduction scheme if it includes—
a company issuing securities subject to conversion, or
such an amendment of rights attaching to securities issued by a companythat the securities become securities subject to conversion.
For the purposes of subsection (1)(a) a company’s securities are securitiessubject to conversion if conditions A and B are met.
For the purposes of subsection (1)(b) a company’s securities are securitiessubject to conversion if conditions A and C are met.

Condition A is that the rights attached to the securities include provisionas a result of which a holder of such securities is entitled, on theoccurrence of an event, to acquire shares in a company by conversion orexchange.
Condition B is that at the time when the securities are issued the companycould reasonably expect that event to occur.
Condition C is that at the time when the rights attaching to the securitiesare amended as described in subsection (1)(b) the company could reasonablyexpect that event to occur.
Debt instruments treated as equity
A scheme is a deduction scheme if it includes a debt instrument issued by acompany that is treated as equity in the company under generally acceptedaccounting practice.
In this section “debt instrument” means an instrument issued by a companythat—
represents a loan relationship of the company, or
would do so if the company were UK resident.
Scheme including issue of shares not conferring qualifying beneficialentitlement
A scheme is a deduction scheme if—
it includes a company issuing shares to a connected person, and
the shares do not meet conditions A, B and C.
Condition A is that on their issue the shares are ordinary shares that arefully paid-up.
Condition B is that when the issue takes place there is no arrangement orunderstanding under which the rights attaching to the shares may be amended.
Condition C is that, at all times in the accounting period of the companyin which the issue takes place, each of the shares confers a beneficialentitlement to the appropriate proportion of—
any profits available for distribution to equity holders of the company,and
any assets of the company available for distribution to its equity holderson a winding-up.
For the purposes of subsection (4) the appropriate proportion, in relationto a share, is the same as the proportion of the issued share capitalrepresented by that share.

Chapter 6 of Part 5 of CTA 2010 (equity holders and profits or assetsavailable for distribution) applies for the purposes of subsection (4) as itapplies for the purposes of the provisions specified in section 157(1) of thatAct.
Scheme including transfer of rights under a security
A scheme is a deduction scheme if each of conditions A to D is met.
Condition A is that the scheme includes a transaction or a series oftransactions under which a person (“the transferor”)—
transfers to one or more other persons rights to receive a payment under asecurity, or
otherwise secures that one or more other persons are similarly benefited.
A person is similarly benefited for these purposes if the person receives apayment which, but for the transaction or series of transactions, would havearisen to the transferor.
Condition B is that—
the transferor, and
at least one of the persons to whom a transfer of rights is made or asimilar benefit is secured,
are connected with each other.
Condition C is that, immediately after the transfer of rights or thesecuring of the similar benefit, two or more persons—
hold rights to receive a payment under the security, or
enjoy a similar benefit.

Condition D is that, immediately after the transfer of rights or thesecuring of the similar benefit, the market value of all the relevant benefitsof such of those persons as are connected equals or exceeds the market valueof all other relevant benefits.
In subsection (6) “relevant benefits” means—
rights to receive a payment under the security, and
similar benefits.

In this section “security” includes an agreement under which a personreceives an annuity or other annual payment (whether it is payable annually orat shorter or longer intervals) for a term which is not contingent on theduration of a human life or lives.
Consequences of deduction notices
Consequences of deduction notices
This section applies in relation to a transaction if—
a deduction notice specifying the transaction is given to a company undersection 232, and
when the notice is given, each of the deduction scheme conditions is met inrelation to the transaction.
The company must calculate (or recalculate) its income or chargeable gainsfor the purposes of corporation tax, or its liability to corporation tax, for—
the accounting period specified in the deduction notice, and
any later accounting period.
That calculation (or recalculation) must be done in accordance with—
the rule in section 244 (the rule against double deduction), and
the rule in section 248 (the rule against deduction for untaxable payments)if it applies (see section 245).

But the company is treated as having complied with subsections (2) and (3),so far as the scheme specified in the deduction notice is concerned, if thecompany incorporates the necessary relevant adjustments in its company taxreturn for the accounting period specified in the notice.
For the purposes of subsection (4), adjustments are relevant if they—
treat all or part of a deduction allowable for corporation tax purposes asnot being allowable, or
